comment: It's a good controller, but if this is as good as it gets, the future of racing games on the Switch is almost nonexistent, the two biggest flaws of this controller are the following:-The ridiculously expensive price tag.

Where to begin...I've always been fine with the Joycons, Handheld mode, in the grip, or one in each hand. I don't mind any of those control methods, nor do I find their D-Pad buttons to be a problem. But I bought this controller for Smash Ultimate and to see what all the fuss was about, because I don't want my Joycons breaking in a moment of carelessness.

Worked perfectly for a month. Then about two weeks ago I was playing Splatoon and I noticed that sometimes when I would be trying to run forward my character would instead walk very slowly. It has now gotten to the point where my character will completely halt for a solid 2 seconds before moving again. In Splatoon, this is absolutely game breaking. I've recalibrated and reset the controller a dozen times and nothing has fixed the problem.I couldn't find any option to contact the seller to ask for repair/replacement so I guess I'll have to go through Nintendo themselves. Very disappointed that I paid $70 for a controller that only worked for one month.

I can't imagine playing switch games without this controller. The regular controller is just a little bit off in how it's shaped and it just doesn't quite feel as comfortable as you want for most games and for playing a long time. The grips are really nice and the feel is clean and button presses are pretty crisp. This controller is very comfortable and surprisingly has the NFC built in for amiibo. The only gripe is that the NFC is in a weird spot and can be a little difficult to trigger. The battery life in this is really good and I've never gone a play session where it's gone dead. Charging doesn't seem to take that long either. If only they had more colors, like a Luigi green. The retail price is a little ridiculous, but it's worth it on sale.

I like this controller better than their WiiU Pro. What I don’t like is the price and that in order to use your old WiiU Pro you’ll need a dongle. They should add support for them, they really should. I prefer the shape on the WiiU Pro better but this one actually feels more comfortable to me. They finally offset the analogue joysticks which makes gaming easier. 40hr battery life vs the old at 80hrs is a step back but they use the exact same battery just this one has hd rumble and an nfc reader. 40hrs is still long enough for even a hardcore gamer. You don’t need the joycons to play the switch. I brought my switch screen and this controller to work and played Mario Kart during lunch. Left the joycons at home. I like that the buttons aren’t so tiny like on the joycons. I have average adult hands and the joycons are just too small for me. I can’t use them comfortably. This is the best wireless option without a dongle.

This is probably the most comfortably designed controller I've ever held. The buttons are nice and big and feel great to press, the weight is good, the sticks feel great, like all Nintendo analog sticks do. HD rumble and motion controls work fine and battery life is worlds ahead of the PS4 controller. The D-pad is a step down from typically Nintendo design though, having no ball underneath the center, so every direction can be pushed in at once, which can occasionally cause problems, but I've played a ton of Tetris and shovel Knight with it and it's still pretty solid. The erganomics are stellar though, to be sure. Feels better than any other controller that I can think of and I think the Xbox one S controller is pretty top notch comfort-wise. Also, with the right Bluetooth controller adapter it can be used on the PS3 and aside from the six axis crap not being present it works perfectly. I blasted through a good portion of uncharted with it just to test it. I bought mine used too which I'm normally leery of, but it's really study and I've had no issues at all. I love it.

Honestly a great controller. Better of course than the Joy-Cons that come with the Switch. The analog sticks are smooth in movement, the D pad suffices, the buttons aren't too small and the triggers are nice. Being an owner of a PS4 Pro and an Xbox One S its my opinion that the Pro Switch controller is the most comfortable I've used. Ergonomic and nice to hold. Shame it doesn't come with the Switch but the controller is a luxury to have so the purchase is worth it.

Ayo I picked up this controller cause I'm a piece of garbage who won't settle for the basic black one, and it got me curious about the game itself so I checked it out and almost 200 hours in Xenoblade later I can fully say this controller is a right slammer. Works just like a normal pro controller, plus it's reddish pink. Now not only can I be more insecure about my masculinity, but all my friends who know what xenoblade is can judge me for liking such a weird-ass game. What more could you want. Unfortunately, I wouldn't say it's worth the upwards of 100 dollars that it's listed for. Just get a normal pro controller if you're not a picky pile of human trash like me, or just use the joycons; you're only playing smash anyways ya jackass and you suck at it to boot.

I bought my Switch last year for Christmas for me from my husband ♥️. I love playing the Zelda games.The Joy controls took a little getting used to. I don't hate them but I don't love them either. I definitely did not want a corded controller, so the Pro A or Horipad wasn't an option (I think that is what they are called) so I just got used to the Joy con controls. My husband has really big hands so he really has a difficult time playing with the Joy Cons. He doesn't play the Switch that often so it wasn't a big deal. I didn't realize the Pro Controller had come out until recently but I didn't really want to spend the money at the time.

I expected this controller to work longer than 6 months. After very light use(I own a ps4, xbox and gaming pc) of the controller, within 6 moths the left joystick stopped working in the up position. I only use the pro controller when playing more than 2 player games like mario cart. I contact amazon support and nintendo support they told me the controller has past the 3 month nintendo accessory warranty, so an exchange is not possible. Nintendo mentioned a $40 dollar repair fee since it is out of warranty. Very disappointed with nintendo because the pro controller is very pricey. Again, I expected this to work longer than 6 months with very light use.

Update 8/31/20: Upgrading back to 5/5 stars! Turns out I accidentally turned motion control on without knowing it. Once I found that and turned it off the issue was gone.Please ignore my negative comment below.

I bought one at Gamestop and the left joystick stopped working after a few months.  I sent it back to Nintendo under warranty thinking it was a fluke and bought another one while it was being repaired.  The first one came back and worked fine but then after a few more months both failed, out of warranty.  The problem seems to be the ball cover of the joystick top rubs against the round opening of the case and creates all sorts of plastic dust that gets into the joystick electronic switches and causes them to fail.  I opened up the case, blew out the electronics and it worked for a little bit but then the problem came back, even though I kept the joystick top clean.  I tried isopropyl alcohol to flush it, vacuumed it out and it worked afterwards for a week of heavy use but then failed again.  I was quoted $25 or $29 to repair.  But instead I bought a third party one and it has worked longer than the other two and continues to work.  Until they fix this design flaw don't throw your money away.  Shame because when it works, its smooth and responsive and has a very nice feel.

Fells a bit more traditional like an Xbox or PS controller.  The joycon seems a bit too easy to click the joystick down on accident while in the heat of battle that was the main reason I got this controller and for a bit more comfort.  The only problem I have with button layout is the + key is close to the Home key and the - is close to the capture button and it can be easy to confuse them or not feel comfortably certain you're gonna hit the right one while playing.  This is minor though as ur usually looking to pause anyway when going for those buttons and if u hit the wrong one it isn't terrible, also u get better as u use it I'm sure.  The joysticks have a lot of room for play yet don't seem to activate untill you've moved them about 50% towards the direction you're going.  Then the last 50% is where u have the control to manage speed.  I.E. if youre trying to walk slowly it feels like you have to move the joystick farther than you should have to before walking begins which leaves less room for control in the stride between walking and running.  This may be fixable in some sensitivity settings I'll have to play around.  Overall though great controller it feels much better playing Zelda with this over the joycon (which is decent itself with the grips)

This is a superb controller with a serious weakness! Five stars for the controller, 1 star for durability! The left toggle switch gets glitchy after two plus months or more depending on level of play, and it seems to be common from what I've read. None of the fixes worked for me. For $70 I expect it to last longer even under a lot of play time. Most reviews fault the left toggle.I bought it after I bought my Switch expressly to play The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild. I found the JoyCons awkward for this game. It is a fabulous, sumptuous and gorgeously realized game. However since this started, it has gotten to be more consistent in it's glitch to the 180 position. Link trots along or runs away from monsters, and as soon as I stop him, he does an immediate about face and starts walking off!!! I can't have him walking blithely to his death every time he stops in a dangerous place. I have to keep pushing the toggle back to get him to finally stand still, and it's become ridiculous, so I'm forced to order another if I want to finish the game! He's walked off cliffs, stood up from a crouch to walk away and been peppered with arrows, scared away game, and drawn the attention of enemies all because this left toggle is suddenly massively glitchy. I tried canned air to blow out any dust, but it seems like a part failure. He almost walked of a Divine Beast in the middle of the air!

It's one of the most ergonomically comfortable video game controllers I've ever used. I have arthritis and cannot play on most controllers very long at all & this controller was a huge change for me, because now I can actually play video games for more than 20 minutes at a time again without pain. I like that you can also use it on PC for Steam games. I had some issues with mine where the plastic hand grips did not line up flush with the controller body and I had to return a few and do a Nintendo repair to finally get one that didn't have that issue, but that wasn't a serious issue and I think it's just that I really hate the feel of a noticeable edge on my hands. The controller does have an issue with the D pad sometimes registering the wrong inputs. I never noticed this problem until Tetris 99. For games like that or 2D platformers that require a lot of precise D pad inputs it is not the best controller. But for 3D games it works well. I loved playing Breath of the Wild with it.

While this is the best feeling Switch controller out there, the stick quality is awful, and it WILL break after a few months of good use. Everyone I know with one of these gets the same issues with the sticks. I just spent $200 on a soldering kit, replacement parts, and fixed my controller after several weeks' worth of practice. But you could just avoid all of that and not buy this thing.

Unfortunately the left joystick started drifting down after about 6 months. I'm not a pro smash player or anything, so it seems hard to fathom that I used it more intensely than most during that time. I also kept it really clean, regularly wiping off the residue that easily accumulates on this controller while in use with a soft, dry towel.The other sad part is that Nintendo isn't taking de-facto responsibility for this issue. After I contacted them, they informed me that Pro Controllers purchased outside of the console are only under warranty for 3 months. After I insisted that I would not pay any amount of money for a controller they call "Pro" that malfunctioned in 6 months and pointing out the similarities with the class-action joy-con suit, the rep put me on hold to see what he could do. After he returned, he offered me a "one-time" free repair.

The rumors that the D-pad was improved for the Xenoblade model appear to be true. I get far fewer unintended button presses on perpendicular axes with this unit than I do with my original dark gray unit. In my opinion, this is the best Switch controller currently available from a functional standpoint.The cosmetic design is quite good and matches the aesthetic of the game well, without being crass or visually busy. The controller also appears with red handles in the console controller menu, making it easy to distinguish at a glance.

El producto se pidió desde hace más de tres meses y no llegó, la tienda contestaba que reenviarán el producto pero tampoco llegaba, les pedí la devolución del dinero y lo único que han hecho ha sido evitar la comunicación al no contestar los mensajes que se les envían constantemente.

I keep giving Nintendo my money.  I bought it as I started playing Zelda BOTW and didn't particularly like playing with the joycons attached.  Hated to lay out another 70 bucks for a controller... but I did and I'm satisfied.  Build quality on this is better than my Xbox, and the battery lasts seemingly forever.  I love the feel of this compared to the Xbox controllers too.  Damn you Nintendo... now I have 4 joycons (for mario cart), plus an extra controller, plus a charger, plus the plastic steering wheels.  What will you make me buy next :).

My left thumbstick broke with light use. The warranty is only 3 months which is not long enough for such an expensive product. The Nintendo Switch console has a 12 month warranty and so should this controller.

I purchased this when I ordered Super Mario Odyssey because my original Grey Joy-cons suffer from the notorious connection interference. This controller is absolutely amazing! It charges over the included USB-C cable that can be connected to one of the two front facing USB ports on the switch dock or any other USB that powers the device according to the specifications. It stays charged for a really long time especially compared to the PS4 controllers. I haven't quite expereienced the claimed "40 hour lifespan" that is advertised on the box but it is well over 30+ hours. If you prefer a traditional gamepad as opposed to the joycons I couldn't recommend this enough. It supports amiibo and features motion controls that can still be used in a range of games. Wonderful product!

I bought this thing because the joycons that came with my console started having issues that recalibrating was not fixing. I was so used to playing with joycons after a year of only using them. They were very comfortable as a controller in their own right, with or without the shell. I still want to get the joycons repaired or replaced someday when I get more multiplayer games/It took me a day to acclimate to the new controller, but it already feels just as, if not more comfortable than the joycons in the joycon shell. It's heavier but not uncomfortably so, it's comfortable to grip for a few hours of gameplay. Most of the buttons have decent feedback. The battery seems to be almost as good as the joycons were, I got mine last week and still haven't had to charge it since the first day.

I used my Wii U's Pro Controller so much that there is heavy wear marks on the analog stick hats.When I bought a Switch, I saw the price tag of this controller and thought it was ridiculous.  A gamer friend chided me, telling me I'd eventually get the Pro Controller.

This is fantastic. Bought so I could play Mario Kart with my 11yo on his new switch (joy cons + adult hands = no good, IMO) I let him figure out how to set it all up and he had it connected and working in less than a minute - so if an 11yo can do it, I suppose anyone can! We didn't bother with the directions. Definitely recommend for playing on the TV.

The Xenoblade pro controller looks and feels great. Big fan of the Xbox controllers. In many ways, I prefer this controller over that. Buttons are big, clicky and responsive. The thumbstick is nice and firm.But this controller is unreliable. I thought I was unlucky or got a defective but I've used two different pro controllers where both the thumbsticks drift even when brand new. Right out of the box, my Animal Crossing character moves without me touching the controller. And the camera moves too.

I play this mosty for PC games and steam. The controller has a nice feel to it and adds so much comfort to the hands from playing games in prolong time. Battery life is what makes this controller shine among the rest, long battery life is amazing, I charge my controller once or twice a month. It's really easy to sync bluetooth via PC to play games in steam.There are three things I do not like about this controller:

I really do enjoy this controller. It feels great in your hands, and I like the weight of it. It's basically a better-feeling version of the WiiU Pro Controller, for anyone who's used that.  70 dollars for it is way too much though, especially when part of that price tag has to do with it having stuff like 3D rumble. Unfortunately, it's pretty much mandatory if you want to play your Switch locally with friends, or even if you just want to play by yourself on your TV. (The joycons are fine as the tablet's controllers, but they're not great when you disconnect them to play on the TV.)This controller's saving grace is that it connects very easily to a computer, making it great for PC games with full controller support. It would be much more convenient if it was XInput, but oh well.

Ever since COVID, Nintendo Switch has been nothing but a life savor keeping my families stay sane and entertained.However, we only have the original mini controllers that came with the Switch console and a poke ball to play with Pokemon Go, so everyone at my family takes turns so it’s been a battle to fight over controller constantly.
Gives such a huge advantage for sport games and especially Fortnite. This makes me wanna play the switch more often. Won't leave without it.Update :
Very rare 5 star reviewUPDATE:

When reviewers say that the Pro Controller (Pro Con) is the controller that should have been the default or should have been the quality used instead of the quality used in the Joy-Con, they were right. The difference is a world apart. The button travel (of buttons ABXY and the shoulder buttons) is too deep for me, however - deeper than the XBox One controller (though not as deep as the XB1's analog shoulder buttons). Limited travel buttons would make the Pro Con even better.The comfort grip - the lower, burgundy portion of the Pro Con - is just plastic. It is dimpled, so it has a texture feel. The back is also burgundy, but it is not textured.

I got this within a week of buying the Switch, and probably the one piece of advice I heard from everyone is "just buy the Pro Controller from Nintendo". I got a cheap 3rd party authorized USB controller while I was buying games in store, played some games but quickly just decided to grab the Pro Controller. After I used it, I realized why everyone loves it. It's almost perfectly built, feels great and natural, and so many features for the controller. Wireless works fantastically, battery lasts forever, Rumble feels good, and the motion controls work wonderfully. The motion controls are probably the biggest here - I didn't realize that games on the switch actually depended on the motion controls, which I really missed out on when I had a third party controller. With this, there's so many opportunities for motion control to provide a natural third joystick, especially in games like Breath of the Wild. Works fantastically. My only gripe is that, since it is so convenient, I love to just throw it in my backpack with my switch and its case, and go out for the day. However, there's nothing supplied to help protect the joysticks in transit. I would have loved to see easily detachable thumbsticks, or some kind of bumper, so that I can quickly store + access the controller without needing a protective case or worrying about the condition of the joysticks getting jostled. I know that's not really a trend with many comparisons, like xbox or playstation, but given what I heard about this controller having long-term issues with thumbsticks, it would make sense to me.

I would 100% recommend any one that has a switch getting this because the joycons are not very durable. I have had my switch for a few months and the joycons are already having problems from just regular use (I am not a huge gamer maybe play this a few hours a week). The left joycon stick is messed up and will keep inputting that I am pressing forward to move character when I have stopped this has caused me to walk off many a cliffs in breath of the wild. Get this and use it anytime you are playing in docked mode cause the joycons will just not last.

I figured I'd be happy with the stock Joy Con controllers in the handle.  My hands are smaller than most gamers, so it was relatively comfortable for me to use them, until I tried to play Mario Kart with my brother with the individual Joy Cons...  Even my smaller hands aren't tiny enough to work them comfortably, and they aren't evenly matched since the buttons are sort of off kilter as a pair.I needed a second controller if I wanted to play properly with someone else.  Enter this beauty!  The Pro Controller instantly has a great feel right out of the box, with a nice sure weight that comes from its rumble pack and internal battery.  It works great if you have problems using the smaller Joy Con controller in its handle accessory.  The controller charges relatively quick, and pairing is easy with the console once you've plugged the charge cable into the Switch base at least once.

I have been a Nintendo Switch owner for almost a year, and while I love the joy-con controller and grip overall, sometimes I prefer a more reliable and "traditional" controller.  I finally picked this controller up on amazon this week.  I love it.  This is one of the most comfortable controllers I have ever used, which increases the enjoyment of my Switch games even more.  The battery life is good, the layout makes sense, and it has built in motion-sensors for gyro-scope aiming, which comes in handy for games like "Splatoon 2" and "Zelda: Breath of the Wild."  The only major downside to this controller is that the button layout for the "pause" and "home" buttons took a while to get used to, partially since the color scheme can make the buttons look similar.  Other than that, I have no real issues with this controller; the battery life is good, and the controller itself is very comfortable, maybe matching the Gamecube controller as my favorite Nintendo controller.  I would recommend picking this controller up for your switch.  I spent months playing hours of Zelda: Breath of the Wild but worried about the stability of the controller I was using to some extent.  Now I can comfortably sit back and play Breath of the Wild for even more hours on end with a controller that feels great!  The controller is a little pricey, but more than worth it.  So pick it up, and enjoy many hours of fun and comfortable gaming!Peace,

I ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT! TAKE MY MONEY, NINTENDO!THE GOOD: Really good bluetooth range, no input interruption while playing the Switch docked from about 10 feet away. Feels great in my hand, and the larger buttons are nice. The D-pad is very responsive and feels as good as the classic D-pads Nintendo has made in the past. Pairing was a cinch and the battery last a long time on one charge.

I bought this last March and all was great. But today the left analog stick broke while playing Mario Tennis. I heard and felt a pop in the left analog stick.Now it will either not recognize down input or the controller gets stuck and keeps the left input pressed. I can hear something broken inside the controller.

Didn’t pay attention that the description say “used-like new” which isn’t the case. The controller frequently inputs Right on the joystick as if I was holding it down when I’m not. If this has ever happened to one of your controllers you know it is extremely frustrating & basically makes the controller unusable in most cases. It’s unfortunate I work overseas in a remote location so I don’t have the luxury of just going to the post office to return this. So I left this review to show my frustration. NEVER BUY USED CONTROLLERS.

This is a great controller, in my opinion it's worth the extra money to get this over the other aftermarket switch controllers, much more comfortable than the joycons, but still a little too small for people with large hands, you'll find yourself with one finger covering the shoulder buttons instead of two like you could comfortably do with an Xbox or PS4 controller. This is technically compatible with PC but you will have to use it wirelessly, and due to some odd bug the gyro glitches out the DirectInput controls if you have this enabled in Steam... so you have to manually choose between DirectInput OR steam, can't do both at the same time, with that said you'll still want to have an XBOX controller on hand for the occasional PC game where you find yourself wanting a controller. Otherwise this is great and a must have if you want to play really long games on your switch like Xenoblade or FE3H.

Out of the box, didn’t work. Kept having to connect then disconnect. It kept getting out of sync every hour and a half, which was a small inconvenience until the y and r buttons had a huge delay when 2 inches away. Then after a *months* use, it slowly turned into thirty minutes. For 80$ I really expected this to be good.. I would really love to return this and get sent a new copy because I believe I may have gotten a damaged version. I would return it but the window is closed.. I would really love to get in contact with an amazon employee, so I can get a refund.. I guess I’m stuck with a controller that disconnects frequently. If you are going to buy this, don’t buy it from amazon. Buy it from your local store.

As much as I love the Nintendo pro controllers, the one I ordered came flawed. When mine arrived, I noticed it suffered from a condition labeled by the Switch community as ‘drift’, more commonly associated with the joycons. If you don’t know, what this means is my left joystick, at a neutral position, will slightly drift to the left without a physical input. This is kinda annoying, but now I’ve had mine for almost half a year, and it hasn’t bothered me much since. There’s no fix to this thats ‘user friendly’, since an at home way of fixing it requires disassembling the controller and messing around with the internal electronics.I’m ordering another one in time for xmas for my girlfriend, but know your controller may arrive with drift.

Very awesome controller. It feels good. Has decent weight and the battery can last over 80hours i am hearing. I only charged it once so far and its been 2 weeks and I use it every day. Not sure if its just a massive battery or the tech is just better. I can't get over 7 to 10 hours in my ds4 controller or over 12 with mt xbox controller with bigger mah batteries. So its really dope to see this. My only complaint is I wish the top was a bit skinnier as well as the buttons, but that is where the nfc chip goes and I wish it had bluetooth for headsets because the switch doesn't and the bluetooth adapters I've gotten for the switch have been terrible.  Another thing I wish it has was an actual toggle switch to flip A and B buttons for people play a lot of ps4 where X is select and circle is back but on a switch A is where circle is and B is where X is. Even when you switch it in the switches settings games struggle to understand what you are doing so it ends up becoming a mess. Other than that the controller is great. Only once did I have drift but I think that was my Joycons doing that.

If you know what a good controller is then you will understand how terrible this controller is. The fact that there is no microphone jack for a 70$ controller is horrible, the fact that Nintendo is based around games that use a d-pad and this is the worst d-pad they have ever released because it misreads your inputs is shameful and half a scam. DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY ON THIS CONTROLLER. You can get a good controller for half the price of this thing that will fit all your needs casual or competitive. And if you’re worried about the amiibos, don’t. Your joycons have the feature so you don’t need to waste your good money on this junk. DISGUSTED

I was hesitant to buy this because of the price tag but pulled the trigger because my left joy con was drifting really bad. I was so excited to get this in the mail thinking that all my problems with drifting would go away. BOY WAS I WRONG. Opened the box, connected it, played animal crossing for a couple mins and BAMMMM my character would drift down to the left. Swear it wasn’t even out the box for a hour n it was already drifting. For $100 you’d think it would last. :( so sadUPDATE:

The controller is great when it works.  A few months out the left controller stick started to "drift" (as many people have complained about in other reviews as well) and when I contacted warranty support they claimed it had only a 90 day warranty -- even though the warranty PDF on the amazon site under warranty information says "hardware" has a 12 month warranty.  Seems like they should clarify what "hardware" is in their warranty -- seems like a controller is "hardware" to me.  Also seems like they should fix/correct the defect in their product since this appears to be a very common problem.

I love the artwork and color choice for this controller. As this is my first Pro Controller on the Nintendo Switch, it works great. Has the same "rumble" feel as the joycons (JOY CON BOYZ) and is just a lot easier in your hands which = less cramps, better ergonomics and thus gameplay is enhanced.Charges with a USB-C cable included in the box. Nothing much else to say. This is great for Xenoblade Chronicles 2/Switch fans and those who love the color theme!

i bought this controller months ago when i first dove into the Nintendo switch for the upcoming super smash bro ultimate game that was coming out later this year.  i think i used it once when i got the geezless thing when i first got it and just left it and the console plugged in for a few months seeing that i really only bought it for smash. today the day before release i thought id give the thing a go just to make sure everything was fine and ready to go for when smash releases and the stupid thing wont connect. ive updated the system, ive updated the controllers, i plugged it into the dock and the damn thing will not connect. i even did a factory reset. you hit the sync button and the lights just go back and forth endlessly. and smash is legit hours away from going live too..

I bought two of these. They are great controllers.  Unfortunately, on one of them,  the left joystick activates downward every few seconds.  It has a mind of its own. This is devastating in Zelda BotW.  Yea, I’ve recalibrated, blah blah.  Several times.  Turns out this is a regular defect.  Just google it.  For $60, that’s shameful.  You can watch it on the calibration screen.  Just randomly jolts downward when I’m not even touching it.

Update: Purchased this just over a year ago and the controller is having alot of glitching issues. Expected better purchasing an official Nintendo product. Specifically purchased Nintendo name brand for that reason. I can't recall if I was offered a warranty when I purchased, but it doesn't appear I purchased one. If it offers you one... Take it! We paid over $70 for this, so would have been worth the warranty.  Nintendo, this really should have lasted more than a year.Previously review:

So I purchased this Nintendo Switch Pro Controller on a deal for about $50, which is a super deal. Regardless of the price the Pro Controller has been an awesome companion for my Nintendo Switch and now more, sinde Joy-Cons started drifting.This controller is wireless, no crazy delay, and it works! Love it comfortable to play with.

Very disappointed. I was excited to get this controller that everyone has been praising for being ergonomic and having a long battery life. Here are the problems I found:- The thumb pads are not sticky enough so my thumbs kept sliding around and I had to put a lot of pressure to keep my thumbs on without sliding. This was tiring.

I was torn between buying this Pro controller or another set of Joy Con controllers + grip. The latter was actually more expensive but naturally you could turn the Joy Con into two smaller controllers, accommodating more players. However, I went with the Pro Controller and haven't regretted it since. I use my Switch docked 70% of the time and this controller makes gaming on it perfect. The build quality is superb, the buttons are responsive and it just feels premium. I've been using it for about 20-30 hours so I'll be sure to make an update around the 1 month mark (which is when it seems the left joystick craps out on a lot of these controllers). If you play a lot of solo games docked, get this controller. The Joy Con + grip is definitely serviceable, but take your game up a notch with the pro especially if you play games like Splatoon 2. Highly recommended, so far.

This controller just may replace the second-gen Sega Saturn joypad as my favorite first party controller ever.  It's comfortable as can be to hold, but I have just one concern.  The analog sticks rub on the face of the controller and wear the plastic down, it's white powder around either analog stick.  I just hope Nintendo is going to be supporting to their loyal players in a year or so when these things start wearing out.Back in the N64 days, the Nintendo customer service number on the sticker on every Nintendo product took care of their gamers and they sent me three new N64 Analog sticks for the controllers that got worn out for free.  Just the analog sticks, and I had to take apart the controllers to put them in.

When I picked up my Switch a few years ago, I picked up a pro controller to go with it. Why? Because I knew that I would use it on my TV a lot, plus with bigger games like Zelda Breath of the Wild and Mario Odyssey, I knew I would enjoy them much more with a standard controller. The pro controller reminds me a little of an Xbox controller, but a little bulkier. However, after time, it really fits your hands well. It's high quality and again, awesome to use if the Switch is either your main gaming console or your only gaming console (which it is for me). I also love it for games like Super Smash Bros, DOOM, Witcher 3, Skyrim and other titles. I would say, though, with the expensive asking price, if you use your Switch mostly in handheld mode or if you are only a casual gamer, or do most of your major gaming on another console/PC, then I'd probably pass on picking one of these up.

Was exactly what was advertised and works great with the console. One issue I have run into is when using it with any kind of emulator on the computer, the joy stick does not seem to be calibrated correctly. Using the OpenEmu emulator, during many games the character will not go into a full run forwards, and will go ridiculously fast if I pull back making them go in reverse. I do not notice this with the games on the consoles I’ve played on, so maybe they are able to adjust for the miscalibration while the computer programs just can’t seem to calibrate it totally correctly. My solution has been to switch the controls to the D-pad while playing emulated games. Overall, it’s great though, and much more comfortable than the joy-con controllers that come with the Switch.

I finally upgraded to the pro controller after much time contemplating if it would really make a difference to me. I've been using the joycons since the launch of the Switch and while not perfect I can still appreciate their design concept.The one aspect of the pro controller that had me on the fence were the triggers. Honestly, that is the one thing I really don't like about the joycons. Everything else about the joycons I can work around. Well, pictures don't do the pro controller justice, the triggers are absolutely fantastic and I certainly don't see myself ever using the joycons again when it comes to playing games that utilize the triggers extensively.

Ended up returning. The joysticks on the controller are much different than on the joycons that come with the Nintendo switch. Personally, after playing in handheld mode, and switching to the docked version playing with the pro controller, I noticed the joysticks are much bigger and you have to push them “farther” to get any response in the game. So it felt as though there was a lag after using the joycons which have as much “smaller” or I guess “shorter”? Joystick. For me, I did not like the button design shape or size, as it did not enhance my playing experience

At $70 (I guess they recently lowered the price to $60), this thing really ought to at least operate correctly. I mean, sure, everything on it functions as intended... except the left joystick likes to "drift" and register inputs that aren't being made... even when it isn't in use at all. Lovely.The d-pad is middling at best... there are plenty of better third-party options out there, especially the 8BitDo controllers like the M30. The Pro feels fine and all, but that drift... oh, and the placement of the Home, Capture, +, and - buttons are kind of odd, making it very easy to hit something you didn't intend to. Sure, it has amiibo support which no third-party products can have (and do we reeeeeally care?), but so do the Joy-Cons that came with the system.

I purchased this to play Skyrim on the Switch, particularly in docked mode.  Now, the Switch comes with a plastic holder that you can slot the half controls into to create a standalone controller for free.  I'll call this the "standard" controller further down.  So, why pay $60 or so for this?Well, in contrast to the standard Switch standalone controller, this has a very different feel to it.  Because the controller is larger, the left-thumb control has a lot more "play" to it.  This means there is more distance from the center to the ends.  This gives me more precise control in-between the edges when using this than the standard Switch controller.  And that can be crucial for some games.  The standard Switch thumb control can only move a very short distance from center to end, making precise control between the edges much harder.
This is a Great Controller albeit at a price that's harder to swallow.I bought this alongside 8BitDo's SN30 Pro+ and both controllers have their pros and cons...

Bought this so controlling the Switch would be easier, obviously. This works so much better than the Joycons. I like to play Overcooked where it’s really essential that you turn and pivot real fast and with the Joycons, sometimes I just want to smash something because it just will not register at all. This is all fixed with the Pro Controller although I only got one so basically my boyfriend and I have to fight for it.I hate that it’s so expensive but it’s also so ’necessary’ so Nintendo just takes all my money and I guess I’m okay with it. Battery lasts pretty long and charging is easy through USB-C. It also supports Amiibo so I don’t know anything about that. It definitely feels better and is more comfortable as well than the Joycons in the controller shell. Clearly a sales tactic. But it’s working.

This makes playing the Switch much easier. I don't have huge hands, but after two hours of playing using the Joy Con controllers (both attached and detached from the console), my hands felt stressed and a bit cramped.This controller feels like it was made of a higher quality than most and is somewhere between the PS4 DualShock 4 and the Xbox Pro Controller in terms of feel and quality. I absolutely love it and after playing for about 10 hours on it over the past week, I can say that if you intend to play Breath of the Wild or any other games on your TV that require a controller, this is the way to go.

I've bought two of these. They feel great, but the left joystick breaks after about 40 hours of use from white dust that collects under the joystick. The fix is to buy a new controller or disassemble and solder in a replacement joystick costing $12.

For a 70 dollar controller, this thing feels FLIMSY. If you lightly shake it left and right, you can hear stuff moving in them. And the grip handles of the controller are wobbly . Not built to last it seems. But love the feel and look of it. Nintendo needs to step up.

If you are a switch owner, this is a must have controller. This is probably my favorite controller of all time. The way it fits in my hands, it becomes a part of you. The buttons are clicky and the directional pad is much better than using the joycons. The battery life is amazing and it charges quickly through USB-C.If this worked cross platform fluidly, this would be my go to controller for all video games. It's very similar to the Xbox One controller, but the grips are a little bit thinner and I'm just able to get a more solid grip than the Xbox One controller.

UPDATE MAY 2020: Not that badSo after I wrote my initial review, I was able to get the stripped screw off (and destroyed the grip in the process, having to order replacements from ebay). Then over the ensuing months I tore apart the controller probably 20 times, trying different variations of the tape trick to fix the D-pad with varied success. The tape did largely correct the false inputs, but at the cost of sometimes not registering button presses. In the end, I decided to take off all the tape and use it as it was originally designed to be used, and guess what? It isn't all that bad. Sure, when you do the input test in Switch settings it registers LOTS of false inputs, but this is less noticeable during actual game play. Now granted, I'm not a professional gamer, but I used the D-pad extensively to play Rayman Legends and Super Mario Maker, and it worked just fine. So in conclusion, yes, the D-pad is far from perfect, it's a major blemish in an otherwise perfect controller and a disgrace for Nintendo, but NO, it is not as bad as everyone makes it out to be. It's probably still the best Switch controller out there at the time of writing. My advice is to buy it and spend some time actually using it before buying into all the negative hype and trying to mess with it. It really isn't all that bad. (with regards to my original review, everything I had said about the design and ergonomics still holds true, even with the aftermarket replacement grips I had to install).

This controller is fantastic at first, but is destined to have problems. Know that if you buy a Pro Controller, chances are, you WILL have problems down the line. It's such a bummer that this is a common issue among Switch owners. I take great care of my things, and my Pro controller has 2 significant problems after about 6 months of use.1) Left stick issues. When pushing the left stick upwards, the controller experiences what I've been calling "reverse drift" -- it pulls the input down. I've calibrated dozens of times, and this fixes the issue momentarily, but it always comes back.

This thing feels really well built. The controller has a good quality feel to it, plus it feels just the right weight to make it feel secure in my hands. At first it felt a little big since I had been using the joycons mostly, but i quickly got used to it. The price can be a bit hard to justify, but i paid it since I knew that it wasnt a gamble. There are cheaper options out there that might feel this good, but i knew FOR SURE, that this one would be good. And it didnt dissapoint.Pros:

I personally love the pro controller. However, mine came completely defective straight out of the box. I even bought mine brand new figuring I’d have less of a chance of getting a defected one. I bought a pro controller about a year ago for a friend and hers works beautifully and hasn’t had any issues since- but mine came with a drifting control pad and half the buttons didn’t work, had severe lag, or didn’t have any response whatsoever. I tried updating the controller but there were no updates for it. I was having issues with my right control paddle that came with the switch console so I got the pro to avoid that, only to get a controller that had more issues right out of the box. Amazing. Nintendo has seriously forsaken the quality of their newer controllers. I expect much better from a product that costs so GD much.

...the Directional Pad is *very* subpar. If you're only going to use it for accessing features or items like in Super Mario Odyssey or Breath of the Wild, it works just fine. However if you're going to use it for retro or 2D games it leaves much to be desired. There's no central pivot point like in most every good D-Pad allowing you to hit Up, Down, Left, and Right at the same time and they are sensitive so you will be hitting directions you don't mean to. There's ways to modify it and there's tutorials all over YouTube, but you will have to disassemble the whole thing to do it. I have yet to do it but people have said it makes it a lot better.That said everything about this controller is fantastic. It's not a nice weight, feels quality. It is by far the most comfortable controller I've ever held. It lasts seemingly forever. It says 40 hours but I've yet to put a dent in the battery icon even after extended play. Motion controls are flawless and precise. If it wasn't for the D-Pad I'd say this is the best controller ever made. I don't know why Nintendo dropped the ball on that considering they are the ones who perfected them.

We LOVE the Switch but weren't fans of the teeny tiny controllers for two-player games. I bet they're perfect for kids but my hands are just too fat for that. We bought two pro controllers (one for me and one for my husband) and just love them. We feel like kids again, playing MarioKart after the actual kids go to sleep!

Two of these were delivered November 30, 2018. By March one of the joysticks was malfunctioning. Have tried recalibrating several times but it doesn’t improve. The joystick physically moves, but doesn’t communicate to the game properly. For example, in Splatoon while moving through the plaza the character will run, then walk very slowly, then stop, then walk slowly again, then run. It’s not reliable for gameplay.We have no complaints about the second controller. Battery life is very strong.

This takes an almost perfect controller and fixes my one complaint, the "D" pad.  There is now a pivot for the "D" pad which fixes any issues with pushing directly up or left and right without it going in both directions at the same time.  The design is very nice, but I do wish the red was more bright.  It is more of a pink than a red, but that is a tiny non-function affecting preference.  It might not be worth it to buy this as a replacement, but if you don't have a pro controller I highly recommend this

Out of 4 new controllers, all of them eventually developed problems. Either the joystick starts giving weird feedback (like moving forward is jerky), or the d-pad starts messing up. Tetris 99 is UNPLAYABLE with my pro controller because about 30% of the time I hit the left button, it also triggers the top button which drops the block down. When I play with the joycon, I have no problems.These controllers feel great to use until they stop working properly. We sent one to Nintendo to be repaired and the one that came back developed the same problem.

Nintendo. I am very displeased. The Joycons have this issue already, and I didn't expect it from this. However, I am guessing they use the same hardware between the Joycons and Pro Controller because the left thumbstick pulls. I just bought this to replace another that started after two years of use. It started happening to the new one right after the return window closed, too.I am so disappointed, but they are willing to work with me to do a free repair. I will revisit this if anything else notable happens.

Solution to calibrate pro controllers in Animal Crossing and fix automovementsI wrote this solution to solve the drifting in games like animal crossing with pro controller in other thread, and it worked for me and other people than reply me.

I bought a Switch Controller to replace the one that was stolen from me.It came dirty which was to be expected but the left bumper is completely broken and does not work, the left trigger does not even press in.

I had been using the pro controller for about one year before the left stick started drifting down. I cannot use the controller at all because the drift is so bad that it drastically pulls down during gameplay and in menus. A quick search online shows that this issue is not rare. Due to the price of this controller and the stick drift problem,  I cannot rate it higher.

With 20,957 reviews and climbing fast, will you ever see mine? I specialize in tech reviews and even if not, here’s the “Pro” scoop. We compared the $70 Nintendo version to two of the highest rated generic ones, the excellent Funlab and the YCCTEAM. I will include links to those reviews below:In short, for RUMBLE effects, the Nintendo is more subtle and responsive-- the others work fine but the rumble is a bit overdone. Otherwise, the generic controllers are both terrific. Nintendo wins the battery life battle but in practical terms this is a non-issue. Who wants to be playing for 30 hours straight?

The sticks are nice in that they are in the same layout as the Xbox-style of controllers, but I am not a fan of the Playstation-style triggers. The quality of the build seems on-par with 1st party controllers, but the price tag is just stupid. And the HD rumble is just so weak, I would prefer it to just rumble at full power, because I can't even tell where the "HD" part comes into play due to it being so feint.It's nice that you can use it on PC/Steam, I had to use it for Rocket League while I was waiting for a replacement Razer Xbox controller (btw, do not buy Razer controllers, they last until the 1-year warranty is nearly up, or a little after, and replacing it does not extend your warranty). Sorry, tangent there, but using it for Rocket League felt a bit jarring even with the similar layout, I never got used to it, probably mostly the triggers...

Over the last few years, Nintendo has been largely absent from the "Pro" Controller sphere.  The last Nintendo Pro controller was for the Wii U and with very little use, it didn't last very long.  I had mine for about a year and it stopped working.  It felt cheap and in the end, it was indeed cheaply made.  With the Switch Pro Controller, we finally get a high quality handheld controller.  It feels great in your hands and I would say it's a must-have for docked gaming.  Some complain about the d-pad but I haven't had any issues thus far.  It's a bit expensive but it feels expensive (more so than the last Nintendo Pro controller); there's a certain heft to it. (It's not heavy but it's nicely weighted.)  Highly recommended!

I like the feel of the switch pro.  I played a ton with with controller over 9 months until the controller would occasionally drop down inputs.  I swapped out the pro controller in a realtime competitive multiplayer game, and my performance instantly improved.  The pro controller is slow and laggy.  I'd recommend avoiding it.  Certainly better than joycons, but it's pricey with weak performance.

This controller is awesome. It's almost big enough for my ape-sized hands (by far better than anything else out there, comfort-wise) and the battery lasts longer than any other. This thing got me to 100% on BoTW, and I use it for every other game I play. EXCEPT...This controller is trash for Puyo Puyo Tetris, and any other game requiring d-pad precision. Worst d-pad Nintendo has ever made. It's embarrassing. Each of the 4 directions occasionally presses other directions simultaneously. So sometimes I'll want to go left during Tetris, and BOOM- 2 hard drops in a row. Just like that.

It's a great controller that obviously has a serious defect. This is the second pro controller I've bought that have the same issue. The left joystick (upward control) stops working after a month's worth of play. I primarily use it to play Splatoon 2, which requires the user to use the up joystick motion the majority of the time. It's expensive for a typical controller, but it's worth it because of the motion control; however, as I mentioned, it's got a big defect that definitely needs looking into. I've also researched the internet and other users who play Splatoon are having the same issue.

Purchased in February 2019.The directional pad wrongly registers key presses. This is all over the internet and it's just poor QA done on the product. I bought a switch and this controller, exclusively to play tetris 99. That's all I play.

It’s so much better than the joycons. The joycons are convenient for easy transportation and multiple players, but they left one gets drift SO easily. It’s ridiculous that Nintendo hasn’t solved that issue yet (other than offering free fixes). The pro controller is much sturdier and comfortable ergonomically. The battery life lasts pretty long after being charged. I like it a lot and have no regrets spending the money to buy it.

I thought it might be hard to get used to the controller after using the Switch built-in controllers for a while, but that was not the case. Even though it doesn't feel the same as holding the Switch unit, it feels pretty natural. It has good weight, and the feedback feels almost identical to the Switch joy cons (or whatever they are called). Haven't run the battery down yet to see just how long it lasts, but so far, so good.

This is the first time I have purchased a licensed Nintendo product that was defective and I've been playing NES products since 1986.  The first one I ordered, you had to push the right d-pad really hard to get it to work which is especially annoying with Legend of Zelda breath of the Wild.  I returned that one for a replacement.  Fortunately, Amazon's returns are very convenient.  I've read that there were more problems with controllers for the Switch compared to other consoles both with the pro controllers and joycons but supposedly Nintendo identified and fixed the production issues.The second Pro controller I ordered seems to work correctly so far.  I tried it on Zelda Breath of the Wild for a few minutes but will have to play more this weekend.  This controller is very comfortable just like the Wii U controller and comparable to PS4 and XBox controllers.  Hopefully this one will work for awhile.  I still have controllers for the Gamecube, Wii and WiiU that still work the same as when I bought them.

The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller gives a nice feel and better control handling than the original Nintendo Switch game controller provided with the o.g. purchase of your Nintendo Switch;For the price of $59.99 with Prime Free 1-2 Day Shipping and Handling,Compared to the Nintendo Switch Joy-Con Gray Controller or The Neon Red/Blue Joy-Con Controller,which usually sales for $79.99!Comment: ("The Nintendo Pro Controller will provide a: strong in-hand control,Wired or Wireless control,Rechargable up to 40 hours before its next charge,and Prefect for those lenghty videogames,such as Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild,which can turn out to be a "4 month long" Adventure!

You have to keep in mind if you need a second controller or not. I recently got MK11 so i wanted a second controller.  Playing with 1 joycon each is a cool feature but it’s not comfortable. I looked into the cost of another set of joycons and the controller adapter (idk what that’s called but it comes with the switch originally but not with a second set of joycons) and this would be the less expensive option.I got this as a second controller because i needed one but my main intention was to use it as my main first player controller.

So I’ve bought two of these, one for my little sister yet and another for my little cousin. They both absolutely love it for gaming and hated using the joycons! The controller has a more comfortable hold and I’ve tested it and the gameplay experience is great! However, my little sister’s already has an occasional south drift on one of her joysticks which is frustrating since I got it for her in August and the controller isn’t cheap. But my cousin’s is perfectly fine and bought around the same time. It may depend on the player, but my sister isn’t rough when she plays at all, so it may just depend on the controller you get, so buy at your own risk! May want to consider purchasing at a store like Best Buy or target where there’s buyer protection you can buy along with it :)

I've been gaming since 2000. I've owned every major console since. Out of all the first party controllers that have ever existed, this is the highest quality one I have ever used. I wouldn't say it's worth spending almost 1/5th the amount of the actual console to have, but you won't be disappointed if you do.It COULD ruin your experience with the Switch. It becomes 'another thing to carry' (as the Switch was built with portability in mind). IF you travel frequently and want to purchase this and the Switch at the same time I'd actually recommend waiting awhile before ordering this. Get used to the Joycons. You don't NEED this to enjoy the Switch.

I like getting officially licensed Nintendo products when I can, but the price tag on these controllers sort of delayed my initial purchase as I wanted to buy several controllers for playing with my kids or buddies.  When I started playing a game competivley though, I felt like my response wasn't quite there with the Pro A off brand controllers.The look and feel of this controller in your hand is incredible and makes all the difference, I still think the Pro A off brand controllers are great for what they are, and at a 3rd of the cost, but if you want precision and reliable performance, then you want one of these.

It's a great controller. If you're looking to use something that feels more like a modern controller than the double joycon configuration then this is where it's at. The d-pad is always welcome. The layout feels much less cramped. The sticks feel sturdier and more substantial. The + and - buttons are much easier and more comfortable to access. The only downsides to the pro controller are that it uses standard rumble instead of HD rumble, it doesn't disconnect to operate as two controllers, and it costs an extra sum of money on top of the system itself. But for the amount of playtime you'll get out of it and the comfort it will afford you, it's easily worth the money. This one is a bit plain, but if you're not quite sold on the concept entirely yet then you probably won't mind knocking off a few bucks to get one without some special design.

This controller works perfectly with the switch, but i find the Joy-cons a lil more comfortable to play with, they are more versatile, and when attached to the comfort grip, i cannot tell much of a difference. When i go my son his Switch, i bought one of these Pro controllers, and an extra pair of Joy-cons, and i'm glad i did, cause whenever we play together, we rarely use the Pro controller, as i prefer the Joy-con as well as my son does. I think this controller may be a lot more appealing to someone who comes from another gaming platform and it's used to that controller layout, but we are just starting into the whole gaming theme, and as my son is growing older, he's starting to ask me for these video games.

I originally bought this controller because I hated how difficult it was to play Super Smash on the regular switch controllers. The sticks are too small, and I feel like that whole controller is better suited for portability and smaller hands.The price of one of these controllers is HALF of what it costs to get a second set of Joycon controllers and a grip, so I was a little worried that it was going to feel cheap and unpleasant to hold. Thankfully, this isn't the case.

I waited a few weeks to order this, so I had plenty of time with the Joy Cons in different configurations.  But for games like Zelda: Breath of the Wild I found the Joy Cons attached to the default dumb controller attachment that comes with the Switch to be a little wanting.  My hands are a bit larger, so it's very nice to have a larger full controller to work with.One thing I did experience, the first time I sync'd the controller to my Switch I did have some small instances where the controllers tilt functionality was hesitant or laggy. (Example: When using my bow in BotW, it just didn't want to fine tune my targeting by tilting the controller.)  But it seemed to correct itself after only a few minutes of use and I've never experienced the issue again.

The Switch Pro Controller works pretty well, but I wish there was a hard-off, as it will turn itself on in travel and if you are using your Switch in handheld mode and someone or something messes with the Pro Controller, it will hijack your game. This also can prematurely drain the battery. It is comfortable to hold on my medium to large sized hands and a bit daintier than the replaceable battery version by the same brand. Charging is convenient with the same cable I would use for the Switch. Can be used plugged in. After a while of use thumb caps tried to pop off. I make sure they are seated well before a session of play.

I tried the xbox 360 controller route with an adapter-- which I loved, but there was lag and dropped connectivity from time to time-- which was hellllllaaaa annoying. i decided to get an actual nintendo controller, and I gotta say I am very happy with it that I got 2 more. The only thing is that the LEFT/RIGHT may sometimes act like UPPER LEFT or UPPER RIGHT.. so playing something like tetris 99, you might accidentally do a hard drop when you didn't mean to. There's a youtube video online that shows you how to fix that by leveling the D-PAD up, haven't tried it yet. Overall it feels good in the hand because those joy-cons are too tiny. Also the officially licensed nintendo ones,  PowerA, those are not rechargeable-- you gotta use batteries. happy I got these, you can just use the USB wires to charge.
UPDATE:Don't go refurbished on these in my opinion. Never was able to charge the controller. The orange light indicating charge never came on. Unfortunately have to return this bad boy.

I love this controller. I own the switch obviously and the Xbox one and ps4 and this is my favorite controller out of all 3. It is not only a fantastic design but it also feels as good as it looks, making the long gaming sessions of Xenoblade Chronicles 2 that much more enjoyable. In my opinion it was well worth the extra 5 dollars for the looks. Also the buttons are the same "emerald green which I didn't notice at first but is a great touch. Would highly recommend this product.

Thia controller is awful. I bought it to replace my other controllers that have joystick drifting issues and as soon as I turned thia new one on to use it, it started drifting horribly. Ita even worse than my older controllers. I would give zero stars if i could.Edit: just in case anyone was wondering I bought thia controller new not used

I bought this recently so I can start playing some games with my older son. He's been all over Let's Go Pikachu for months now but we recently picked up Smash Bros. Ultimate and Fire Emblem Warriors. This controller style is very similar to the original Xbox controllers after they reduced the size from the original monstrous ones, which I actually liked.Playing Smash Bros. on the Joy Cons is very difficult for me, maybe because I'm from an other generation that is used to everything being on one device. Having the Joy Cons separated and trying to do combos was very tedious as the buttons weren't where I expected them to be as a result of my arms moving around during game play. I could attach them to the static controller accessory that comes with the system but for me that's too much work. When I want to play, I want to play. I don't want to fiddle with accessories much unless it's going to bring a major enhancement to the game play.

Nintendo knocked it out of the park with this one! It's as comfortable as a PS4 controller with the analog-pad-stickiness of an XBOX one. The D-pad, which isn't separated like the Joycon's, is much better for fighting games.The battery lasts a long time and I LOVE that Nintendo decided to use the USB-C standard for charging. As it becomes more ubiquitous, I think most people will appreciate this as well. Now I can bring one charger for my laptop, switch and controller when on travel. (Take a hint, 3DS)

I like to play the Switch from time to time but I'm not a huge gamer. After receiving the system as a gift, (thanks, wife!) I tried using the Joy-con to play Zelda and Mario. It's doable, and not an issue, but I was used to the psx, xbox and older controllers.I found the pro controller online and saw it had great reviews. I decided to spend the money and try it out. I'm glad I had!

This is honestly the best controller I've had since the Wavebird, back in the Gamecube days. I own a Switch, but I really got this for my PC.If you haven't connected it to a Nintendo Switch in your house, you can use the bluetooth functionality to play it wirelessly on PC. But once it's been connected to Switch, you'll need a USB-C to connect it to the computer.

Every button on this feels amazing, the controller feels very solid. And built in battery too is great. I had to get this because I sit about 10ft away from my TV and the joycons seem to have trouble at that range. This has complete solid connection and fixed my issue, but after using it I realized just how uncomfortable the joycons are relative to this. If you like using the switch docked a lot it’s definitely worth the buy. And you’ll have two controllers for split screen as a bonus. I have quite large hands and this feels like it was made for me

I think that this controller is the best controller that you can buy at the moment. It fits well in your hand, it functions almost perfectly (the d-pad is below average, but not awful, better than og gc controllers), has a long battery life (it hasn’t run out on me since I bough it), and has seemingly no input delay. So why don’t I give it 5 stars? Because there are a bunch of tiny things I have gripes with that don’t apply to 99% of games. I think that the tops of the control sticks are too wide, but I enjoy the c-nub that comes on the gc controllers that a lot of people dislike. I like to slide my fingers over the face buttons when mashing our of grabs in smash, and these buttons roll a little to much for my liking. The fact that the sticks also don’t have notches are good in some scenarios but bad in others (an example is when trying to do macro wavebounce neutral specials in smash; it’s harder to do them bc of the lack of notches, but much it’s easier to play shooter games like warframe and splatoon). The point I’m trying to make is that, if you’re not me, you won’t have any problems with this controller at all, other than the d-pad being bad.

If I had to pick my favorite controller from this generation of say that the Nintendo Switch Pro beats put the Xbox One Pro Controller and the PS4 dualshock. Comfortable grip for long play sessions, responsive buttons, comfortable sticks. As all controllers however I have my gripes. The D-pad, although far better than the buttons on a Joy-Con, is not the best Nintendo has ever put on a controller. This disappoints me a lot, I've owned many Nintendo systems and their D-pads have always been the best in the industry so to see this decline is a personal gripe I can't help but share. I do prefer triggers with feedback, but you won't miss much with the simple button like design on this. The biggest merit of the Pro Controller is the built in gyro, playing shooters is a far far better thing with this gyro enhanced aiming. Don't believe me? Play Splatoon 2 with and without it. Although awkward as you get your berrings, it will soon become natural and you'll find yourself unable to shake the habit of expecting all controllers you use to react to your subtle hand motions.Good controller, would recommend.

This controller doesn't require one to have large hands like the X-Box.I originally bought a "PXN" off brand pro controller for my Switch. Well, surprise, that one ended up with left stick drift after a mandatory Switch firmware update. Factory reset it multiple times and it starts to drift again within a couple minutes. This only happens when paired with the Switch. When paired with my PC or my Pi it works fine.

I have large hands, and I find that most controllers are smaller than I'd like (many are much smaller than I'd like). It's been years since I used a controller that I thought was large enough to sit well in my hands (Logitech used to make one that I really liked, but it's probably been at least 15 years since they stopped making it, and their more recent controllers are all much smaller). Historically, the Playstation controllers have been particularly bad. The PS4 controller is much better than previous generations, because they adjusted the shape to make it less cramped, but it's still too small. The XBox One controller is a much better size, but for me at least, it hurts my hands to use the RB and LB buttons because of how I have to twist my hands to press them (whereas with the PS4 controller, it's really easy to move my fingers between the R1/L1 and R2/L2 buttons). The Switch Pro Controller is not quite as large as I would like, but it sits far better in my hands then either of those controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've tried in recent years), and while it's not quite as easy to move my fingers between R/L and ZR/ZL on the Switch Pro Controller as it is  on the PS4 controller, it's close. So, for me at least, the Switch Pro Controller is far more comfortable than either the XBox One or PS4 controllers (or any 3rd party controller that I've found in recent years). So, from a comfort standpoint, this controller is a _huge_ win for me. No other controller is even close.I very much wish that the analog sticks were lined up like they are with the PS systems. Most of the controllers that I've used over the years have had the analog sticks on the same level, and I much prefer that to having them staggered like the XBox systems do and the Switch Pro Controller does. However, the comfort improvements with the shape and size of the controller vastly outweigh that problem for me.

This works PERFECTLY with hobby retro game emulators that use 3 dollar bluetooth adaptors. (ODROID XU4, Raspberry Pi 3b+)Some wireless USB devices over bluetooth are problematic in 2018, and not premier quality, including various Wii-U wireless , and some PS3 wireless... but THIS IS AWESOME AND IDEAL for 2018's "Wolfanoz 400gb Special Odroid XU4 Image" and for 2018's 256GB PiPiggies.

I bought this thing because the joycons that came with my console started having issues that recalibrating was not fixing. I was so used to playing with joycons after a year of only using them. They were very comfortable as a controller in their own right, with or without the shell. I still want to get the joycons repaired or replaced someday when I get more multiplayer games/It took me a day to acclimate to the new controller, but it already feels just as, if not more comfortable than the joycons in the joycon shell. It's heavier but not uncomfortably so, it's comfortable to grip for a few hours of gameplay. Most of the buttons have decent feedback. The battery seems to be almost as good as the joycons were, I got mine last week and still haven't had to charge it since the first day.

I was “forced” into buying my first one during the great Switch shortage of 2020. GameStop bundled a switch, game and a controller together. No switch by itself. It was actually one of the best deals seeing as amazon and eBay only had switches marked up by 2-3 times.I ended up really liking this controller. The joy cons are too small to use as an adult. My hands would cramp after a little gaming. The GF ended up taking over my switch with ACNH and this controller. So when I finally was able to get another switch.  This time through bestbuy with no bundle. I decided I needed this controller for myself again.

Super comfortable controller, probably one of my favorites! The only gripe I have is connecting it. My SO and I each have a Switch, but purchased one of these to share. In order to pair it, you have to briefly plug it into the console you want to connect with. No easy connecting with the shoulder buttons like the Joycons have. Once it's paired though, it stays paired. Battery life is fantastic. I still rate it five stars because the pairing issue is a unique one that most people will never experience. Definitely worth the money!

I used to be like pretty much everyone else with controllers: Xbox 360/one/s were the gold standards. However, this is my favorite now. It feels much more solid despite how it looks. Everything is in the same general format but for some reason it's easier for me to use. You can even use it with Steam if your PC has bluetooth!There are only a few issues:

Is an okay controller and takes some getting used to for certain games. Not recommended for incremental movements for games that require motion detail, unless you're willing to spend extra time practicing for that specific game or unless the game has that all movement where you can physically direct the controller to position on screen. Once you know how to work it, it's okay; the joysticks are kinda stiff meaning they either go one way or the other and you can't move just right in a smooth, slow motion if you need to do it quickly like a computer mouse. Does last a long time on one charge which is a huge plus.

I was skeptical of buying this controller since I was initially thinking that buying a pair of joycons would be the better option since it supports two users instead of a fixed one user; however, after months of playing with this controller and sharing it with my friends, I found out that both products have its uses and the pro controller is outstanding on its own. I was shopping for another pair of joycons, but instead I caved in buying this item from youtube reviews and friend recommendation, but I do not regret it for a second. I've had this product for a long time now and I use it for every game I've come across coming to over 50+ games. It is comfortable with a lot of features including rumble, gryo aiming, amiibo support, and compatability with a lot of games. The quality of build is also beyond expectations as this controller has been dropped well over 10 times from friends including myself without any hardware damages or any significant cosmetic damages. Not to mention, drift concerns are not a problem here since those affected the joy cons only. I would just like to sum this up by saying that as an Console user (Xbox and Playstation), it is a great way to ease into controls in switch games and it can be a lot more reliable, comfortable, and easier to play games on the switch. (Even if you play Smash Ultimate, it can be a great substitute for a joycon (unless you are a gamecube controller loyalist that is good on its own too))

I have big hands, so the Joy-Con controllers that come with the Switch are difficult for me to use (and they tend to lose sync every so often, which can interrupt games).  The Pro Controller is almost exactly the same size as an Xbox One controller and feels just as comfortable to me, the sticks and buttons are good quality, the battery life is great, and it charges quickly.  And I have not lost sync with this controller once yet.  I received a second Pro Controller as a gift, and it works just as well, giving me a lot of flexibility.The only complaint I have with this controller has less to do with the controller itself and more with how Nintendo designed some of its games to work with the Joy-Cons.  Super Mario Odyssey, for example, has a few specific moves that can only be performed on the Joy-Cons because they require the Joy-Cons to move independently, which you can't do with the Pro Controller.  Thankfully, none of these things actually make the games hard to play.

The Pro Controller is well worth its cost. It feels much more natural playing a game with a 'real' controller over the Joy-Cons with the grip attached. The only noticeable downside is that a few games don't support it at all, such as Super Mario Party and the Pokemon Let's Go games. Since I had exclusively been using the Joy-Cons from launch up until very recently, it took about a day to get used to the new sticks. They are stiffer to move, but are much more precise. The weight of the controller feels similar to that of an XBOX 360/ONE controller and it's very easy to transport. The charging cable can also be used for the Switch itself through a laptop or other USB outlet which is very useful. The controller also works with Windows, through Steam. Again, very good purchase that I am happy with and highly recommend.

I know, I know... blasphemy, right?  I am more of a traditional console gamer and I like the solid feel of the Pro controllers.  I have three Pro controllers and three sets of Joycons.  My kids and I choose the Pro controllers over the Joycons almost every time.  Not that the Joycons are bad, but I've found that I have a harder time getting them to sync and they don't feel as solid. The Pro is a nicely designed controller that really feels good in the hand.  Of course, there are certain games that only use the Joycons, but they are few.  The rest of the time our Joycons are paired together to act as full controllers anyways, so... save yourself the money and get a Pro controller.  You won't be sorry.
Great controller all around. Yeah it's a bit more expensive that a PS4 or Xbox One controller but I believe it's worth it.Pros

This controller gets 2 stars because of it's comfort. However, I'm 2 for 2 on d-pads that register the wrong direction half the time. A simple google search will reveal how wide spread the issue is with people coming up with at home repairs. I can't perform the at home repair cause it appears one of the screws is so cross threaded I can't get it out. It's a real shame because barring the d-pad issue it's a great controller.

Sturdy and comfortable to hold.Works fine on PC. While most games do not support it natively, Steam offers native support. So if you launch other games using Steam, you will be able to use this controller without issue.

Really comfortable and battery life is great. This is way better for anyone who doesn't have tiny hands. The joy-cons are not very ergonomic and have tiny buttons.
