Great controller...except for a wonky D Pad recording left/right presses as ups/downs. This is glaring in games (eg Puyo Puyo Tetris) where  mispress can create havoc on gameplay.I'm writing this review as a warning: please wait for a new batch of controllers or try a stopgap via charging grip + Joy Cons. I went 0 for 3 on these controller attempts at GameStop. The last was in front of a Nintendo rep (who happened to be there)...who witnessed it all firsthand. Note these were verified in System/input method test. She ended up removing all the batch on hand for being defective.

The left analog stick on the unit I received had a permanent drift no matter what I did to calibrate, and during calibration the stick could not reach the 4 directional inputs reliably.The digital triggers were also disappointing, with a lip on the bottom edge that felt like it would eventually catch on something and snap off.

the controller is comfortable as expected and it works well. however is not worth $70. The PS4 controllers is 30% less expensive and is far more comfortable and well design. But i get it nintendo needs to make some markup. the triggers dont feel like triggers they fill like a regular bottom

I bought one of these locally at Wal-Mart with my first Nintendo Switch since given away. I am buying another Switch for myself and I'll buy another Pro Controller (on Amazon because they're cheaper than WalMart) but I was looking to see what third party controllers have come out since I last looked.For the most part, I still think this is the best wireless controller for the Nintendo Switch. The only one close to it is the PowerA one. The PowerA wireless controller is very comparable though and has different features that I feel most gamers would use. By this I mean the back customizable buttons and the option to use rechargable batteries instead of needing to charge the controller through USB-C. That being said, I feel more comfortable buying the "Official" one made and sold by Nintendo. Knowing it's made with top notch plastic parts that just feel right and it just works and always should (except the D-PAD sometimes doesn't work right I've heard.)

Before you even consider buying one of these, Google "Switch Pro Controller Left Joystick Drift" (you won't need to type much since it's a top fill result...). I've now bought 2 of these, got them in, charged them and started playing with them and both had terrible left joystick drift down and to the left, enough to turn my character around and make me start walking that direction 25% of the time when I let go of the left joystick. These were both brand new. Googling the issue and hoping it was just a calibration thing or something, it's clear Nintendo used faulty equipment in the Pro controller, and it seems to be specifically bad on the left joystick. Now I get to return another one. These are $70, the most expensive game controller short of the Pro controllers on XB/PS, and there's absolutely nothing "pro" about them - no extra features, no modifiable button distances, and apparently no quality control. There are years and years of results about this, and things have only gotten worse since it seems they're shipping broken out of the box equipment now. Nintendo only puts a 90 day warranty on these, which clearly means they know they're garbage and don't stand behind their hardware at all. I'm extremely disappointed, and done with Nintendo brand accessories. If I'm going to get faulty trash, I may as well buy 3rd party for 1/3 of the money. By the way, after 3 months, Nintendo will charge you $50 to "fix" your faulty controller, and ship you back another faulty piece a month later. They've known they're faulty for years and continue using the same known-bad switches and sensors. Avoid at all costs.

I bought this controller as I loved the look of the controller when I saw it online and after seeing it in person, I knew I had to have this controller. People say the grip is Pink but to me it is more of a Red shade than Pink. This controller truly is one of the best I've ever used on any console. I own an Xbox One and PS4 as well, but the thing with the this Nintendo Switch Pro Controller the weight and Resistance on the joysticks just feel right (The weight especially). The only part of the controller that might seem a little off is the massive d-pad, but you get used to it quickly and it's very responsive. The main thing where this controller kills its competitors is the battery life. I've used this controller now for 20 hours and there is still at least half of the battery life left, that is astounding. It's also great that this controller charges using USB-C as you have so many options for charging.I decided to buy this limited edition controller as I also bought the limited edition version of Xenoblade Chronicles 2 and the thought of having a matching controller considering the price difference between this and the regular Pro Controller was too small to pass up. Overall I wish it were a little cheaper (The Pro Controller in General) but it is what it is, with the amount of gaming I'm going to get out of this thing for the life of the Console, it'll be worth it :)

The left joystick on the controller i just received is not working properly. I can move the joystick in any direction just fine, but the characters in the game are not responding the same in each direction pressed. For example I can be moving Rex (from Xenoblade) in almost any direction and he runs just fine, but when I push the joystick to the left he slows down to a walk. I can be moving him an any direction but when I want him to go left, he barely moves. My original pro controller works just fine, but the Xenoblade one I just received; the joystick's inputs are not working correctly.

The controller feels fantastic in your hands.  This is especially apparent after trying to use the tiny joycons with their even tinier buttons and joysticks.  If your an adult with moderate to large hands you need this controller.  Playing games like Resident Evil 5 or Doom feel worlds better with a controller that is designed for hands larger than a 10 year old's.  Using the controller mount for the joycons is not a substitute for a pro controller.  After using the pro controller, you realize that the joycon's tiny buttons, joysticks, and shoulder buttons are things you tolerate.  Even if you decide against buying this controller (most likely due to the price), buy a cheaper third party traditional controller.  Comfort - 10/10The buttons are large, which I love, reminding more of the larger buttons seen on the original SNES controller.  The buttons along with the D-pad have a matte finish that feel great.  A special mention of the D-pad must be made.  This D-pad feels fantastic.  Compared to the 8bitdo SN30 pro, it is NO CONTEST.  The D-pad for Nintendo's pro controller is top of the line and blows the third party D-pads out of the water.  The Joysticks feel good, maybe even great.  They have raised edges with ridges for increased grip which feel good on your thumbs.  I still prefer the concave shape of the Xbox One joysticks but the switch pro controller joysticks are comfortable, responsive, and accurate.  Compared to the Wii U pro controller, the joysticks feel less sturdy though.  The Wii U pro controller feel sturdy and require more effort to move them, which I like.  This is not a big deal but I feel some may not like joysticks that have less resistance. Buttons and Joysticks - 9/10
This was a fake controller packaged in an already opened and taped up official Nintendo controller box.
I would recommend it to anyone who plays more than 1 hour worth playing games. The joycons attached to the grip isn't ideal for all games.Is it necessary? No, the joycons are enough to play any game.

So far so good! Responsive, lightweight but not too light. Fits in your hands perfectly and feels comfortable. Awesome because it also works on PC! Holds a charge for a relatively long time and doesn't take too terribly long to charge either.
Works as advertised, but I have to admit that it's still disappointing that the triggers still aren't analog. At $70 it's also a whopping $30 more than PS4 and Xbox controllers with no justification.
The product was not a controller but it was replaced with a clock inside the box. I was hoping for a controller for my switch system but ended up being gypped.

Solid controller, about the size of an Xbox one controller. The triggers are nothing special and could have been better. Definitely over priced don't understand how this controller cost more than an Xbox one or PS4 controller.
The controller was good at first. Then switch updated to 5.0.0 . I was not able to use this after. The control could not be updated with a MAC.
Although its description stated that it was "FACTORY SEALED", it was missing the USB charging cable... There was, HOWEVER, an empty plastic bag where it should have been (in).

If you have large man-sized hands and tend to binge play your games; you may find the joy con controllers a bit uncomfortable after long play sessions; you should consider getting the switch pro controllerIn this review I'm going to compare** the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller with the
Really not sure it's worth it after having my left joycon repaired.  But I have no friends to play games with, so that could definitely be a factor.

This controller has my favorite thumb sticks, great battery life, as well as motion controls that work in Dolphin and Cemu. So I thought it would be the perfect PC controller now that Better Joy for Cemu has matured. It’s not though...One issue is the size. I have small hands, but this controller seems like it’s so small that only petite women or young teenagers will probably feel like it’s ideal for their size of hands.

Literally the worst pile of garbage I've ever used. Here's a fun question, what does the PlayStation THREE controller have that's better than this atrocity? For one, the buttons I intended to press actually do what I intended to do. Do you enjoy playing Breath of the Wild, trying to quickly switch to a different weapon and then accidentally opening runes for the millionth time because the D-Pad is such an abomination? If yes, then this is the controller for you. I really hope whoever designed this turd is in a hole somewhere crying, while feeling intense shame from making something so horrible. I genuinely hope sometime in the future Nintendo realized how awful this thing is and puts out a better controller. I've used some truly awful controllers before (Dualshock 3), but this one certainly takes the Cake. What's even more embarrassing is that something so awful didn't come from a 3rd party company like Nyko, which I've also bought some truly terrible controllers from.

This is a great controller except for one big problem....  The Y button is stuck down.  I've only played about 60 hours with this controller and it is already broken and broke after the return policy.  So now I am stuck with an $80 (after taxes) controller that doesn't even work.  I hope they fix the problem with future controllers.

Docked a star for the price. Too expensive and I feel like a moron paying $70. for a controller. However it is in fact a really good controller. The Joy cons were cramping up my hands and causing my fingers to fall asleep. I have a similar experience with most handheld consoles. The pro controller is way better than the Joy cons. The buttons are bigger, there's a real d-pad, great battery life unlike the ds4 that has to be hooked up to life support when you use it. It's a sturdy controller. I also had the Wii U with it's pro controller and I did not like it. I preferred and used the gamepad over the Wii U pro controller. The buttons on this one are properly placed unlike the wii u controller which had the buttons and d-pad where Sony puts there analog sticks. One of the best things about this controller is I know longer have to feel like I'm playing with transformers before I sit down to play on the TV. I can just dock the whole system, pick up the pro controller and get to gaming. No pain either. Yay. Wish I could've had a proper controller in the box. Nintendo likes to over think things a lot. There thoughts must keep them up at night just like me. Lol.

All in all it is a decent controller, and I strongly prefer it over the joy-cons which just don't feel very good.My main beef with this controller is the D-pad. The D-pad on my controller had a tendency to register left/right as up button presses if there is ANY amount of ambiguity in where you pressed. This makes playing a few games very annoying (puyo puyo tetris for example). The solution that I've found to this is to open up the controller and place a small piece of electrical tape in the center of the D-pad contact points on the circuit board so that they are covered about a third of the way. This is not terribly difficult, and guides can be found online. If you do not feel comfortable making this change, then I would say avoid this controller. A guide for the fix can be found with some googling.

FULL DISCLOSURE: I paid for this with my own funds and am giving solely my opinions in this review.I have had this controller since I got my Switch in Dec 2017 and have used it extensively since. I have played upwards of 60 hours of Mario Kart and 25 hours of Rocket League as well as my other games almost exclusively with this controller and can say that it is without a doubt responsive, comfortable, and worth every cent. I also happened to snag it for $60 on Prime day back then as a plus, making my purchase that much more satisfactory.

I gave this as a gift to my cousin because she was using the switch joycons with the joycon grip for the last couple of years.  She puts in hundreds of hours playing games on the switch and was comfortable using the joycons.  Little did she know that the Pro Controller is WELL WORTH THE INVESTMENT! She said it took some getting used to from using the joycons because it felt a bit bigger but once she got used to it, she realized she was missing out BIG TIME! She was super happy with my gift to her.It may seem pricey but that's what great controllers cost!  Think about the PS4 controller.  Those things run around $70-$80.  It's definitely worth it.  I have my own Pro Controller as well and I have to say it's my #1 choice over any other controller for the switch!

The controller was nice at first. Everything working well. Im a light casual gamer on my switch (maybe 3 to 4 hours a week). Short story, i got this controller from target. After about 5 months, the controller started drifting via my left joy stick. I looked it up on google and surely enough, plenty of people had the same issue as I. I tried calibrating, changing grip order, blowing air, etc. Pretty much everything except taking it apart. It keeps drifting no matter what. A little disappointed that this controller does this. My old xbox controllers of 2 years is still working strong whereas this less than a year controller is already dying on me. The controller itself seems cheap despite it's good looks and price point. So just a cautionary tale. Really disappointed.

Big step down from wiiu pro. Too big. Triggers too small. Only one color and the splatoon one looks dumb. Works with bluetooth but cant be used to play anything on pc i tyed and it wont but my wiiu pro does. The worst nintendo controller ever made. Not worth the price by far. Even the betteries dont last as long as wiiu pro. Nintendo failed hard with this controller id rather use my gamecube

Very disappointed....At a cost of $70.00 this lasted me all of 5 weeks.....I found it very easy to use....being a Grandma with arthritis....I really enjoy my Switch with this controller.....but the games I play use the left joy stick most of the time and now it does not work like it should....when I try to scroll through a menu and I stop at the spot I want...it just keeps going and going....and my characters don't seem to move like they should....I might have expected something like this from a cheap knock off....but come on Nintendo!!!  it is a waste of money...UPDATE 1/2/19...I sent it back to nintendo and when I got it back they said nothing wrong with it...and lo and behold it worked fine...then about a month ago it started doing the same thing and then the dpad stopped working like it should and I very seldom use it...called nintendo today told me to gently use a toothbrush around the dpad and joy stick...which I did while talking to him...did not help....it will cost me $40 plus I have to pay for shipping...I told him i paid $70 for this and now another $50 is a real rip off....I guess they know they aren't going to last hence the only 90 day warranty...needless to say I am not sending it back...if I do get another one I will get it from best buy and get the extended warranty since Amazon doesn't offer an extended warranty...

You get what you pay for. If you have the funds, go official and you cannot go wrong. Nintendo is almost like Apple, with a premium price but you're gaurenteed to have the best experience. This controller is just a pleasure to use.

Is this seriously the d-pad that Nintendo expects people to play VC/retro games on?  This is worse than Xbox's!I've been through 3 of these controllers, and there are countless other people with the same complaints online, so I know this isn't just a defective issues, it's a design flaw.  The moment I started using one of these controllers, I immediately noticed that the d-pad is somewhat stiff, has an awkward amount of travel and is slow to pop back.  Even worse, when pressing a direction, it is easy to accidentally press one of the adjacent directions unintentionally.  This is mildly annoying in Zelda (where it will simply bring up the incorrect quick select menu, or call your horse), but it's a HUGE issues on Puyo Puyo Tetris (where it will quick drop your piece before you've got it positioned right).

Amazing controller- no doubt about it. The analogues, face buttons, bumpers and triggers are all solid, it features gyro and joycon HDRumble, and it works on PC via bluetooth. You noticed I didn't mention the dpad. It's dreadful.I bought it, like everyone else, to play Switch games on a traditional controller. It's perfect for any 3D games from Zelda to Mario Kart. Again, perfect. But for 2D games like Shovel Knight, Blaster Master, Gunvolt and Kamiko? Forget about it. The problem is it registers an other direction easily while pressing a different one; hold left and it'll press just enough towards up or down to make it sense up and or down are being pressed. Same for right, and up+down to left and right. You'll make tons of mistakes on dpad intense games that require perfect precision. Can't imagine playig Ninja Gaiden with it.

The controller was great when I first got it. Much better than using the joy-cons. Around 6 months into owning the pro controller, the joysticks started sticking slightly causing characters to spin in a circle. The problem was correctable at first but would happen every few days. Now the sticks are at a point where they are so loose they get stuck to one side and it's impossible to get them back in line. The bottom line is Nintendo needs to figure out how to make these from higher quality materials at the prices they are charging for them. With normal use, I'd expect they could last longer than 6 months.

Unfortunately, the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is a roll of the dice as to whether you will get one in good working condition or not. For many people, the D-pad has significant problems under the hood, such as if you press up, the left and right arrows might also get activated. Nintendo was not helpful with replacing my broken controller (and I unfortunately did not purchase it on Amazon), so I have had to do some tinkering inside the controller.In addition to the gamble D-pad, this controller just feels cheap. The triggers don't have a nice feel to them, very plastic-y and light. And the ABXY buttons can develop a click to them after a short amount of use.

As I said I really like this controller in general. It fits nicely in my hands and it functions much better than the joycons. The biggest problem I have with this controller is the drifting. I'm sure you all know about it and if you don't, look it up. I cannot tell you how irritating it is to be on the side of the cliff or in the middle of a battle and you character just decides to start walking off a cliff on its own or wandering. I have already had to buy a second one with less than a year of use. I am really hoping Nintendo fixes this issue because these things are not cheap and it's ridiculous to have to replace these every year at $60 each.

Tldr: The Nintendo switch pro controller is an absolute must have if you play fast paced games with camera controls such as doom. But only gets 4 stars because of the price and lack of 3.5mm jack.I've had the switch since launch day and have been in love with the joycons from the start. As soon as doom came I quickly realized the down side of the joycons. With the smaller size of the joysticks and poor range it made the game rather difficult to play on the harder

If you're like me, and plan to play games connected to the TV exclusively, you need this controller. There's nothing bad to say about the controller itself, it's terrific. It feels great in the hand, the buttons have that perfect feel to them, the layout is just about perfect and the battery charge lasts forever. Well, technically about 40 hours, and that's very impressive.The only thing preventing me from giving this 5 stars? The price... It's absurd. Honestly, this should have been packaged with the console, as the joycons make terrible controllers for play off the TV. The buttons are too small and the grip just isn't comfortable for long periods. So yeah, including this in the box would have been ideal, but this is Nintendo. At the very least, this controller should be priced at around $39... maybe $49, but that's pushing it to me. But $70??? Come on Nintendo, even you know that's ridiculous.

My son Skyler had this on his wish list. When he has earned items on his wish list, I buy them for him. Looking at the $80 + price on this, I almost spilled my beer. SO,  being savvy with our cash, I looked at WalMart while we were there shopping..AND, it was $56... Skyler got his controller and I got some beer...Now I sit and drink my beer as I watch my boy play his games...Happy kid, happy dad.. (I gave it five stars because he LOVES his controller)..He had the Nintendo cordless switch controller and he said it was "good". BUT apparently this one is more "kick ass and ergonomic", that's my boy!!!

So I got this as a gift.  The overall controller feels good.  It's a good external design except for the + and - buttons.  On the Joy Cons they have a distinctive shape and are both placed very far apart from the home button and screen capture button.  But on the Pro controller they are both round, flat, and right next to nearly identical buttons.  You'll be accidentally pressing the home button and taking screen captures a lot with this controller.  The placement of the - button is too close to the left analog stick as well.  I'm constantly bumping it.  I'm not happy with this cramped button placement at all.My first big issue with the controller started just a few months after I got it.  The left analog stick stopped registering when I'd push it up and to the left or right while playing, everything else worked fine.  I've never seen this kind of issue with any other controller.  Thankfully Nintendo replaced it for me but then All the buttons including the D-pad would act like I was holding down the input when I had only tapped it.  I did some trouble shooting over the phone with Nintendo and amazingly pressing the sync button on top of the controller fixed this new problem.

The Switch Pro Controller was announced to be $70, when you can regularly find the PS4 controller and Xbone controller for $40. I was hesitant to pull the trigger, but when I got my Switch and it became clear that it would become my primary gaming system, I decided to buy it. The 40 hours of battery life, HD rumble and motion controls were the biggest selling points for me; I hate the terrible battery life of my PS4 controller and my Xbone controller is boring.Immediately, the Pro Controller came off as more comfy than the other two big controllers. The analog sticks are perfect, the shoulder buttons are perfect, but the D-pad is occasionally finicky; it often registers an Up press when I'm trying to hold Right to switch weapons in BOTW. The battery life is bonkers, one charge lasts me about a week(I have to charge my PS4 controller every day that I use it). The motion controls rule in games like Breath of the Wild and Mario Kart 8. HD rumble is disappointing, though; just feels slightly better than regular vibration, definitely overhyped.

I have 4 of these in different game-release colors. They're great controllers, the only better ones I have used is the Xbox Elite series, and outside the awesome paddle buttons on the Elite 2, the difference is negligible. One thing that bothered me was that my thumbs often slipped around on the sticks, hurting my performance in tight situations in Mario Kart or FPS. I got some skateboard grip tape here on AMZN and put little circles in the center of the sticks and it's GREAT. I strongly recommend giving this a shot if you ever feel your thumbs slipping!

Pros: Long battery life, ergonomic, didn't have any issues in regards to connectivity/range.Cons: Like all of Nintendo's controllers this Gen, the left joystick slowly becomes entirely unresponsive in directions or drifts making it useless.  My pro controller worked great for 12 months, then slowly started having issues escalating from minor/not too noticeable to unusable over the next 6 months.  If this wasn't a premium priced controller I wouldn't be too bothered but given the price I expect more use than 18 months.

This controller has all the functionality of 2 joy-cons except for the HD rumble and infrared pointer. It is not needed for any games, but it does make the experience feel smoother compared to using the grip with 2 joy-cons. I personally always use my pro controller anytime I am playing single player docked (connected to the TV).I notice it really helps with shooters especially, but also with anything you want to immerse yourself in.

I don't understand how this controller has such rave reviews... I picked it up this morning and was excited to finally have a controller for my switch and utilize it while docked. But when I unboxed the controller like alot of people have said the right side grip was not properly aligned which made a slight sharp edge on the back side of the controller when gripped but nothing EXTREME, and brushed it off. But I purchased it with Crash Bandicoot in hopes to revisit the game with my wife. IMMEDIATELY noticed a huge input lag. For those who don't know what that is, a short and sweet explination is when you press a button it takes about a half a second before the console registers the pressing of said button. So in a game like Crash Bandicoot where you have to time jumps and movements perfectly, it made the game impossible. I immediately boxed it back up and returned to my local Target. For anyone who enjoys precise movement and commands. Or maybe playing a game where it isn't as important (which there isn't really one) this controller is clearly not worth the hefty price tag.

I got a $40 gift card for best buy and used it to buy this and price matched with Amazon to only pay about $20 of my own money for the controller. And I gotta say it's far better than the joycons. While I don't mind the joycons at all and think they are perfectly fine in handheld mode but for docked play the pro controller is better. The buttons and analog sticks are bigger and it has a traditional d-pad (which never bothered me but I know for a lot of people it's a big deal.) It's more comfortable to hold than the joycon grip that comes with the console and the Power A comfort grip. I just hope I have better luck with it lasting than some of the other reviews I've read about this controller. But so far my first impressions are nothing but positive on this controller.
I purchased the pro controller when it first came out along with Zelda, so after three weeks of use I think I can offer a pretty fair perspective on it.Pros

There is absolutely no question that Nintendo has done it again, with the way we play video games thanks to the Nintendo Switch. Overall, they have been a defiant influence for generation on how we play favorites like Super Mario 64 and The Legend Of Zelda. But trying to get a second controller for the Nintendo Switch can by either from the joy-con controllers, or by getting another Nintendo Switch controller that feels more comfortable just like the way people have traditionally felt with Nintendo's past game systems like the Nintendo 64 and Gamecube. The new Nintendo Switch Pro Controller feels comfortable, and works very nicely as a second controller if you want to play against your friends in challenging titles like Mario Kart 8 Deluxe or digital titles like Fast RMX. It works very flawlessly with the Nintendo Amiibo figures for great additions to playing your favorite games. The disadvantage with the Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is that it is more expensive in price than Nintendo's earlier controllers had shown for the previous systems. But overall with Nintendo, you do get a whole for quality at the very end. I still recommend getting the Nintendo switch Pro Controller as a second controller for portable gaming at home.Price: C+

Long time gamer here, mostly PC gamer, but I always like to have the latest console or two for various exclusives. That said, I've used every console controller on the market, for a variety of game genres, and this is by far the best-built and most comfortable one I've used. Works perfectly for almost any kind of game (although I still prefer a mouse and keyboard for FPS and Strategy).I initially bought this only because JoyCons were impossible to find... But now, I'm going to skip buying more JoyCons and just buy another one of these controllers, which brings me up to 4 players! (2 Pros + 2 JoyCons that came with the Switch).
I want to say this is perfect. It feels solid, it has a great battery life.But.

This controller connects using standard bluetooth protocols so while it is mildly expensive you can use it trouble free on android, PC, thingaverse projects, and of course the switch. The battery lasts a really long time. It feels amazing in hand I'm a long time PC gamer but since buying this controller I find myself actually playing the switch and on my phone (games like real racing 3) much more often. I really cant say enough good things about this controller it's the first controller I havent hated the ergonomics are amazing it fits my hand like a glove, also it's very convenient for using a PC like a home entertainment system. What I will say is that make sure you have a phone with bluetooth 5.0 and your phone isnt in power saving mode otherwise you'll have lag.

It's a good controller but, I'm sorry, to pay this much of a premium and NOT have a simple headphone jack, there is simply no way this thing deserves a full rating.  I feel that major oversight easily docks it two points.  I ended up docking it another point because of the crappy d-pad.  Probably 30% of the time, when you hit the down button you also hit the left and right along with it.  There is simply no way that this is a fair asking price for these two unacceptable flaws with a controller. Also, The gyroscope is nice, but it isn't as responsive as the joycons themselves.It's hard to fully recommend this.  Would I have bought it again despite the cost?  Sure, but I just don't think it deserves anything about three stars where it is now and for the price they are asking.  You just might find that the joycon grip works well enough for you.

Without a doubt the best controller for PC. If you are only using it with Steam, it's plug and play (or pair and play if you want to use Bluetooth). Everything works great with steam, screenshot button or even the motion sensor!IF you want to use with steam and with NON-steam games or emulators IT WORKS FINE too, but there is an extra applicaction to install  (BetterJoyForCemu) it will emulate a xbox 360 controller. but the motion sensor will still work with cemu.. which is so good!

Nintendo has created something which is somewhat staggering to think about with the Switch. A console so adaptable that it's potential is nearly endless. Along with that comes Nintendo's ability to develop and sell a variety of accessories like this controller. It's a beautiful piece of equipment and likely will prove necessary with many games when compared with the underwhelming and poorly designed joy-con (as a controller, not necessarily when held separately). Nintendo has found a way to receive a massive amount of hardware revenue after the initial sale of the console with the Switch, it just seems that they could price these items a bit more fairly.

Apparently a bad manufacturer (really a vendor) defect. The vendor supplied joysticks (ALPS, same company has supplied thumbsticks for Xbox and PS as well) for this controller that have a lot of plastic parts, and insufficient lubrication. So before long you’ll notice the thumbsticks make really loud squeaks and may even have difficulty physically returning to center. In this case you’ll need to contact Nintendo for repair or replacement as it’s not a case of you dirtying the controller, is the various plastic pieces that make up the gimbal rubbing against each other without enough lubricant - your DIY options are severely limited (disassemble most of the controller and apply cooking oil via Q-tip or similar lubricant, automotive or o-ring silicon grease would probably work great, to the gimbal joints underneath the thumb pad) as the thumbsticks don’t disassemble once soldered onto the controller board. ALPS seems somewhat to blame here, but they also make thumbsticks with metal components for other brands like Xbox. I think Nintendo got greedy and asked ALPS to quote them on a cheaper part number. For as much as you pay for the pro controller, skimping on the thumbsticks from their supplier is a really bad move. This generation of Pro Controllers as a result are probably better avoided. If you have one you’ll want a small, flat tipped Phillips screwdriver and some grease agent to try and apply extra lubricant to free up those squeaky joints.

One of the first purchases I made for my Switch after owning it for a day. I even went inside a store which starts with a W and ends with "happy-to-pay-workers-enough-that-the-government-has-to-support-them" to buy it because it was sold out on the 'zon and other halfway decent retailers.I'd call this a must-have for anyone serious about the Switch as a living room console and traditional gaming. It is a fantastic controller, and well worth the price. In fact, it really only has a couple of downsides, of which there's only one which is an issue.

This controller really needs way less stars. It's a rip-off. The D-pad has major issues that seems to affect everyone. If you play a bunch of 2D games like me, you'll find incorrect button presses left and right. You can even see the incorrect presses from the Switch settings menu. My left and right seem to register as up half the time. Called Nintendo, they want $40 to fix this already expensive controller. It looks like searching online that won't mean it's fixed. You have to open it and fix it with tape apparently. Just wow, $70 for that.I should have just bought the unofficial bluetooth dongle for $20 and used a superior controller like PS4 or the WiiU pro controller. Save your money and do that now. There is no reason for such an expensive controller to be so cheap.

The best purchase I’ve made for a Switch, period. I hate the feel of the Joy Cons, as they’re very dainty and I’ve had to perform repairs to my son’s Joy Con due to drift issues.  When I purchased my own Switch, I knew I’d be playing in docked mode and this has been a phenomenal controller.  It feels solid and premium, and is on par with XBOX One controllers.  I just hope it doesn’t suffer from weak internals like the Joy Cons do.  Time will tell.

The big concern off the bat-- yes this is a very expensive controller.That being said, it is by far the best controller I have used. The quality and grip feels excellent, it is very comfortable to hold and grip for long gaming sessions. The sticks have a nice rubberized textures that give just enough grip. The buttons are nice and big so there's no chance you'll accidently press the wrong button. They also have a nice response and travel to them, so the whole controller feels very responsive.

This controller is essential if you want to game on the Switch. Not only does it feel great in the hand, the offset joysticks (like the Xbox) are a welcome change from the Wii U controller. However, I've never been sold on the reversed XY and AB placement that Nintendo chooses to use on its controllers. I'd prefer if I could change the order of these buttons. I prefer the layout on the PS4 and Xbox controllers and I'd like to put this same layout onto the Nintendo controller.After switching from the Xbox One or PS4, I am forever finding I press B instead of A or Y instead of X. It always takes me at least a week or so to get back into the Nintendo layout. Sometimes I just forget and press the wrong button. This is a real problem that Nintendo refuses to address. For any gamer who's used the Xbox or PS4 for long enough, moving to a Nintendo is a very frustrating experience. If you're going to give us a Pro controller, let us swap the AB and XY placement to match the Xbox or PS4. This is supposed to be a Pro controller, right?

This is the best controller I've ever used. Fits great in the hands, The Zr and Zl triggers are some of the quickest for press *cough Game cube cough* Great for replacing those Junkie Joy-cons.The problems with this d-pad is that while pressing down you and tilt it left and right, and that can be really annoying if you actually need to use it.

Great controller when compared to the Joy Cons.  The downside is that the Dpad (on mine) is sticky and isn't precise.  The sad thing is that they did not include analog triggers (everything is digital, which means either it's pressed or it's not.  No pressing halfway with these) which is going to be tricky to do good racing games.  But the controller is nice, solid, and is worth getting so you don't have to always use the joy cons.  If hooked up to a TV, get one of these... well, even if you play on the go but have a place to set the system, get one of these.

I bought this because my xbox one was overtaken by my kids.  They wanted me to play fortnight with them on the switch so I bought this controller.  If you are used to the joy stock on an xbox one controller you will be severely disapointed in this controller.  The sticks are WAY to stiff in the center making fine corrections impossible in FPS games.  I will be trying something else.

Best Ninty controller since the GameCube’s. Probably THE best controller since the GameCube’s. What a step up from the Wii U’s garbage pro controller. Perfectly weighted, excellent battery life, super cool smoked glass front. Just feels great in your hands, very much like the 360’s did but with a proper D-pad. Great for Zelda, great for DOOM, great for Shovel Knight, great for whatever. If you plan to play in docked mode, get this controller, no questions asked.Two suggestions though:

I'm a streamer, and i play Super Mario Maker 2, and since it has several platforms such as Super Mario Bros.. Super Mario World, and Super Mario Bros.3,  which all are old school side scrolling levels, I use the D-pad (directional Pad), you would think that for $65 after tax, the Dpad would actually work, when you press left the character looks up, or starts climbing if there are vines (ladder). it makes the game unplayable, because you are constantly moving in every direction. JUST BUY THE CHEAP SWITCH CONTROLLER, IT SUCKS JUST AS BAD, BUT AT LEAST YOU DIDN'T DROP $65.

I am only a casual gamer.  We had a Wii.  One of our kids bought a Switch last year, and my large hands didn't like the tiny joycons very much.  This is a good solution.  I'm still not fond of the layout of the 4 primary buttons, but at least I can play Mario U and Mario party with the kids now.

It’s fine as long as you don’t need the D-Pad. I never buy 3rd party controllers because I know nothing beats the original. When I had a Wii-U, I didn’t regret dropping the cash for a couple of pro controllers. However, this sorry excuse for a pro controller for the Switch is just utter crap. Go buy something cheaper because it’ll be a better investment than wasting your time with this piece of trash.

This pro controller is more ergonomics than the built-in controllers that come with Nintendo Switch. My hands are not extra large but I still do not like the built-in Switch controllers.Reasons why I love Switch Pro Controller:

This review sits in the middle of the road because, I must say it is not a bad controller but it has one major design flaw that ruins it for me. Like most controllers, the handles are bent going outward at the ends and inward at the top. This one, it's almost just straight down grips. My huge man hands do not enjoy this one bit and I find holding this thing for long periods of time isn't great.Also that D pad, just lol.

A friend at work recommended I buy the Pro Controller and at first I thought it was a needless expense but he was right: it's great!! I'm so used to this kind of controller already, it makes playing my Switch so much more enjoyable. It's wider and the grip is more comfortable. The buttons are also closer together which is paramount to kicking butt in a game. It also pairs immediately with your switch by plugging it into the back using the included USB cord which was always an issue with all other consoles (which sync button so I press first and where the hell is it?!).Now I have 3 controllers: the pro controller and the two joy cons included with the Switch! It has 40 hours of charge for gameplay and when it runs out, you can switch (get it?) to the joy cons without having to stop to charge your controllers! This controller is the best!!

What's up with the L stick Nintendo!? I've bought two of these and BOTH of them have malfunctioned with the L stick not working properly. AND I've already sent two in for repairs (had FOUR total controllers so far) and they ALL had the same L stick failure. I'm not the only one experiencing this too. It's a big problem. FIX THIS PLEASE!

Tbh I only got this item because I thought it would be a major upgrade from the joycons( mostly because of the drift) I've played several games with it and still haven't gotten used to the amount of travel in the joysticks. I love it for being a pro controller, there is nothing wrong with it. I'm not a d-pad person but I'm kinda glad it's there. But in all honesty if your a person that has only experienced the joycons then prepare to feel a little out of touch for about three days.

D pad issues are still unresolved. The switch has an onboard test that lets you see which buttons are being pressed, and this registers lots of error presses when you press one button. Errors in Tetris and occasionally zelda.. this will become more apparent when more fighting games come out.

The price tag is daunting for sure, but this controller enhanced my game play experience exponentially! It's extremely comfortable, and the battery life is seemingly unending (I have literally NEVER had it die on me... Played for days on end without it dying, and finally decided that I should probably charge the thing). I love this controller so much, and I will always recommend any Switch owner to just bite the bullet and get at least one.

I'm sure there are many Switch owners that are perfectly happy using the Joy-Con.  I'm not one of them.  This controller solves a lot of the problems I have with the Joy-Con.  The Pro Controller comes with it's own USB-C cable and with a full charge it has outstanding battery life.  The Pro Controller also has an ACTUAL d-pad as opposed to the "directional buttons" on the Joy-Con.  I experienced none of the connection issues I had with the Joy-Con and synching this with the Switch took just a few seconds.  The Pro Controller also feels much more substantial in the hand.  The "ABXY" buttons are beefier and provide a more satisfying button press.  While I hesitate to say any accessory is a "must have", this one comes close.  If you're looking for a more traditional console feel and don't mind the slightly steep price tag, I highly recommend the Switch Pro Controller.  Rating: 9.5/10

The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is very well built, it's comfortable, has some weight to it and has textured grips to keep the controller from slipping out of your hands. There's no creaking or bending of the controller while playing, It's the alternative choice for those who want a more traditional way to play games compared to the Joy-Cons setup with the standard Attachment or Charging Grip. It comes with a USB-C cable and can be charged from the Switch docking station or AC adapter.It's an overall improvement over the Wii U Pro Controller, ditching the odd right joystick placement and moving it below the primary buttons, resembling a Xbox controller. It also has larger trigger buttons up top and larger X, A, Y, B buttons which are certainly welcome but it does still lack the pressure sensitive secondary analog triggers that both the Xbox One and PlayStation 4 controllers have - I personally like having that when it comes to racing games. The analog sticks feel smooth and rise slightly around their circumference to prevent your thumbs from slipping off.  The classic D-pad makes a return again on the Pro-Controller, It's the same size as the d-pad on the Wii and Wii U Pro Controllers. It feels responsive and has the solid quality clicks you've come to expect from Nintendo controllers but I found that in a few instances, I've accidently click one direction when pressing another, thankfully it doesn't happen to me all the time but it could be improved.  The + and - button placements are easier to use compared to the Joy-Con setup and are more in reach this time around compared to the Wii U Pro Controller but I wish the buttons would protrude outward more like the Wii U Pro Controller. While playing and without looking down at the controller, I find myself feeling around the for the + or - buttons because they sit almost flush with the controller face and it makes them somewhat difficult to press. The Screenshot and Home buttons also sit very flush and sometimes I'll accidently end up pressing them instead of the - and + buttons.

This is no doubt one of the best Nintendo controllers I've ever felt, but the downside is that after a couple of months the left joystick starts to drift and it's because of the wear and tear of the joystick rubber so I've replaced one of my controller's rubber joysticks but that only solved a little of my problem I also need to replace the Analog Joysticks Thumbsticks! You can find a replacement for the Analog Joysticks Thumbsticks here on Amazon and those were a great buy as well.

I play smash bros competitively. The feel of this is great and I don't notice any extra latency. When it works, it's great...and then everyone encounters the same problems that Nintendo still hasn't fixed.First, especially for smash bros players, the snapback on the left joystick will make you go the opposite direction when you don't want to. Just a little flick, but it can really mess you up while you're playing. If you're familiar with the terms, this controller frequently will make me B reverse in the air when I don't want to. There are fixes for it, but it requires opening up the controller and soldering part of it. If you don't have the supplies to do that, congratulations, you get to pay EVEN MORE for this already overpriced controller.

The hardware is just okay, but its certainly not worth the price I was expecting something special for over 100$ how I was so mistaken, I'll only give it 3 stars for being pc and mac compatible but isn't plug and play you have to install software like steam and set it up for your games within the program, its a bit fiddly unlike just plugging in your xbox pad and it works straight on windows with no problems.The button layout doesn't even come close to being as good as either the xbox one pad or the playstation 3/4 one, but it is better than those generic pads you can buy your for pc or console.

After about 4 months of owning this controller it started to have issues. First, it would no longer turn the Switch on remotely when using the Home button. Then it progressed to having big problems pairing with the Switch, despite many troubleshooting attempts, including following Nintendo's troubleshooting guide. After a couple weeks of this it stopped turning on at all. When contacting Nintendo, they told me that accessories only have a 90-day warranty, so a repair will cost nearly $50 with shipping, handling, and taxes. I purchased an official Nintendo controller expecting exceptional quality and a company who stands behind their own products. So I was very disappointed to find just the opposite. If you want a $60-70 disposable controller, then go ahead and buy this one. Otherwise, I'd suggest looking for an alternative.

Bought two of these and after about 6 months one has the very common left joystick drift issue. After about 45 minutes of “tech” support they wanted $30 to fix it with additional $10 shipping charge.They told me Nintendo issued an “unofficial recall”  on the regular joy cons with left joystick issues but didn’t include the pro controller!!!  Needless to say I will be purchasing only 3rd party pro-style controllers going forward.

I got this controller to make my Switch feel more like a home console in docked mode. With over a year of use, I can safely say that it definitely improved my experience with the Switch. It may be pricey, but the technology inside it is quite impressive, featuring Near Field Communication (NFC),  Accelerometer and Gyrometer for motion control, and advanced "HD" Rumble, meaning it really stands apart from other controllers. The only complaint I have with it is the D-Pad. It feels bad to use, and it is designed in a way that causes it to misread input.Pros:

I only wish it had analog triggers, but honestly no games so far have really had the need for that (I find that on my xbox one controllers when playing racing games, I'm flooring it 100% of the time lol).The layout and feel is spot on. The control stick are without A DOUBT the best I've ever used, aside from those on the Xbox Elite controller (which is a rip off price anyways). They have constant push-back and smooth movement, and after well over 1000 hours of use, the sticks still have no wiggle at their dead zones and still click without issue at any angle. Even if you don't have a switch this controller is fantastic for steam games or emulators.

I bought one of these from Wal-Mart and it lost all bluetooth functionality after a couple months. I could use it when it was connected directly to the switch but after a few more months it wont even turn on when its connected. I've tried charging it with its original charger for days but I've had no luck getting it to work again. If you are thinking of buying this controller or a similar one I strongly recommend getting the warranty with it.

*5-11-17 edited to add last paragraph as well as an extra sentence in the previous paragraph*Let's get down to brass tax here.  This controller feels cheap.  The plastic is nowhere near the quality of even 3rd party controllers on other consoles.  The triggers are also horrible as are the bumpers.

This controller is great to hold in my hand and has an Xbox 360 controller feel. The buttons are a lot larger than the Joy-Cons and are a lot easier to hit. The D-pad is a great addition too, as I always feel this was lacking from the Joy-Cons. I do still have issues with the Z buttons as they don’t depress as much as I would like.PROS

Works great! It’s basically, the same layout as an Xbox controller. It’s way better than the Joycon controller.. honestly my 5 star review is for the quality of the product. But for Nintendo making is buy the REAL controller for 60 bucks? What a scam. They ship it out with a joke controller with almost no battery life, so you’re forced to give them more money.

This is a fantastic control!  The buttons are much larger than those on the joy cons. The sticks are nice and tight and the directional pad is fantastic! In my opinion, the directional pad itself will make this control the best way to play games on the eventual Virtual Console. The joy cons are nicer than I expected, but PS4 and XBox players will find themselves right at home on the Pro Controller. I am confident it will enhance my enjoyment of every Switch game I play. I highly recommend this control to anyone who wants the best experience on the Switch!

It's the Pro Controller, but for the Switch. It keeps many of the themes of the last Pro Controller model, but tweaking each individual element. The sticks have a slight different, but very comfortable tension - they'e a nice height. The contentious change comes to the new stick layout, which is staggered, with the left control stick higher up above the directional pad and offset from the right control stick which sits below the classic Nintendo face buttons. The triggers keep the theme of having a simple button press, rather than implement any pressure technology and keep the usual design. The aesthetics are very interesting and the black faceplate is actually made of a translucent plastic, harkening back to some of the good old GameCube gear, and personally I'm a huge design. It keeps the massive battery life of the WiiU model and brings its charge into the modern age, with a USB C port rather than the bizarre choice for a USB mini on the old design. The controller "handles" have a new texturized "grip" which is aesthetically pleasing but not incredibly adhesive - fine by me. The whole matte aesthetic is a massive improvement than the fingerprint gathering shiny black plastic of the last model...Gamepads are really a person to person thing. To me though, there are a few stand out models that have emerged over time, and for me this joins the ranks of the DualShock 4 and the Xbox 360 controller, replacing its older brother and far outdoing it. I definitely see that many people have a problem with the price tag, but in my experience it comes with the territory (especially when such high quality is demanded over controller input these days.) To those people I say to use the "butterfly" joy con grip that comes with the console - it's really not that bad.

This controller is perfect. It's light, but not too light as you feel it will slip out of your hands. The buttons don't feel weak at all, very high-quality and sturdy. The analog sticks as well feel great; they are very responsive and very ergonomic, and the fact that they included a D-Pad is even better. One problem I have though with it is that the positioning of the home/screenshot buttons and the start/select buttons. I constantly find myself going to the home menu when I need to pause, or going to a different menu when I want to take a screenshot. I feel it would be better if they were reversed.

If you're playing a lot of single player games or online you should definitely get this controller instead of more joycons. The joycons are definitely more fragile and susceptible to wearing down and should be saved for playing games with others in person. The pro controller is really worth the investment since you won't have to continuously spend money on repairing or replacing joycons. Overall, it feels sturdy and has a nice shape that rest easy in the your hands.
Solid piece of gaming hardware. If you play with your switch in the dock this is a necessary piece of equipment. It is pricey but I feel that the quality justifies it. Must own!

The Pro Controllers for Nintendo Switch charge fast and last for hours.  The controllers are wonderful until they break.  Both Pro Controllers we purchased didn't work after only a few months past warranty.

I don't regret buying this thing. Yes, this controller is pretty expensive, but you get what you pay for. First of all, the buttons are quite a bit bigger than the joycons. The placement of the buttons is quite a bit better too. You can easily and comfortably reach all of the buttons with your thumbs. It also has an AMAZING 40 hours of battery life. It also charges INSANELY fast! You can get 50% of battery after just 10 minutes on the charger! Last but not least, the controller is way more comfortable. Every game I've played was more enjoyable with the Pro Controller than the Joycon Grip. This is truly the best Nintendo Controller since the Gamecube Controller. If you own a Switch, it's absolutely worth it.
This  was a gift for my Daughter in law.  She loved it.  It works as described.  She was excited to get it for her birthday

I purchased this item at Gamestop for 69.99 and I love it. The bumpers are more like soft nice silent buttons, where the joy con's are loud hard buttons. Honestly I would buy this controller just for the buttons. They are so smooth and quiet. At least quiet for me, milage may very. I would purchase this item whether  you have the switch or not, it is a must have in your life.

I've owned two of these.  As others have noted the left stick will fail.  So, in a game like Splatoon your character will move slowly forward instead of quickly because a full forward push isn't registered.  This is a very common problem reported among Splatoon players.  So, this isn't a question of if it will fail, but when.  To my knowledge Nintendo has not acknowledged the problem.  Until they do, you should realize you're buying a highly disposable product.

I don't believe the controller I purchased to be broken, but in three months it started scrolling down constantly. Never once, has this controller been damaged by user error. Something about opening up the controller and brushing out the dust. Time, Speed, Distance... I'm happy with my PS4 controller it's top of the line, and never once has this controller been damaged by user error. However, I have thrown this controller, crashed on a skateboard on the controller, and covered the controller in saw dust. The controller is five years old.

Well I rarely used this thing and it lost charge very fast everytime. They claim you should get 40 hours out of a charge , however, every time I picked the thing up, it was dead. Now, after being out of town for a month, I try to turn it on and it wont even turn on, even while its plugged in.I called Nintendo technical support, and the warranty for this was 3 months. Like I said, I was out of town for a good portion of that and am outside of that 3 month window when I picked it up again and it wouldn't turn on. A repair would be $30 plus $10 shipping plus tax. Needless to say, I'm pissed with the poor craftsmanship. I'm having joy-con issues too, but their warranty is 1 year. Makes no sense to me, this pro controller is in pristine condition. I expect more for my $70, and now I have an expensive paperweight.

This is a great controller and very comfortable in your hands but very expensive with 40 hours of play time I recommend getting this if you just bought a Switch (should have came in the box) enjoying every minute of it so far.

Both pro controllers we purchased started drifting on the left stick. This seems to be a problem with these controllers. I purchased a beboncool controller instead and they work great plus were cheaper

Excellent controller. I've had them all and I can easily say that this is my favorite. However, many of these have a fatal flaw with the d-pad. When pressing left and right, the controller registers as up. Many people claim to not have this problem, but try doing a Shoryuken input with your character facing right and you'll see. According to Nintendo, this is due to a problem with the circuit board. Send it in and they'll fix it.The point of this 'review' is to help spread awareness.

This controller is a lot better than the regular Joy-Con controllers that come with the Switch. I feel like I have more control over my movements in games and much more precise. Also the battery life is amazing with my personal experience being roughly 30 hours or more. The only negative to the Pro Controller is the price. If it's about $55 or so, that's a decent sale. Anything higher and it just seems to high. Definitely worth a buy if you want a better controller.

I got this for Christmas two years ago and I absolutely adore this controller. It's comfortable, has a premium feel, and huge battery life. You can leave this thing uncharged for a good week and it'll still have enough charge to last you next week. It's an absolute joy to play Breath of the Wild and Splatoon 2 with this thing, as well as other 2D games like Sonic Mania Plus. However, the only real gripe I have with it is its price point. It's around $70-$65 which makes it more than a new switch game and that feels pretty ridiculous. It's understandable why its that high with how much tech is crammed into it, but it still hurts. If you have a child or teen who tries to scrape together money to buy games for their switch, this makes an excellent gift. Its premium quality makes everyone want it, but its price makes it hard to buy which is why kids or people who are on a tight budget will appreciate this as a gift.

I've used a lot of game controllers in my life, & this one is one that tops them all. It takes about a week of extensive use for me to need to recharge it again. It's a good size for adult hands; an issue that the Joycons that come with the Switch had was that they were tiny, but the Pro Controller seems much more suited for longer use without cramping your hands trying to push buttons on a small controller. The lack of proprietary drivers and implementation is a welcome addition. With bluetooth on your PC, you can connect the Pro Controller and use it with Steam to play most games that support controllers.The one gripe I have with it is there isn't analog triggers, but digital ones. For people that aren't familiar with controllers, digital triggers means that when you touch the trigger its either in an off or on state. Analog triggers means that there's a middle ground where you can half pull the trigger and it counts as half pulled down. A game you might notice this on, that is on the Switch, would be Trials Rising.

The difference between my motion aiming in Splatoon 2 with this and my joy-cons is day and night. I was already doing fine but this controller took me to the next level. This is one seriously well built, sturdy controller, edged out (only slightly) by the godly Xbox One controller. Add in the gyro control and NFC reader and it's a no-brainer. With 40 hours of battery life, I have yet to need to charge it. All of this being said, the pro controller gives no specific advantage in any games (except possibly fighters that use the d-pad). If you think you're scraping by with just the joy-cons, you're not. If you have a switch and a little extra cash, this is a no-brainer.

It's great, ergonomics are spot on. While this is more expensive then the competitors controllers, it's also better. With 40 hours of battery life and feel that rivals the Xbox 360 controller, arguably the most comfortable of them all. With amino support, had rumble and motion control, they have fit a lot of tech in this. Only complaint I can give is that the triggers aren't true triggers, and just click. Aside from that I would highly recommend this for anyone looking for a high quality replacement to the "Grip".Also with the included USB C cord, which is good quality as well, it gives you a way to charge your switch on the go, assuming you don't already have one lying around.

OK, so it has a price tag of $69.99 which is $10.00 abo e the average price of say a basic Xbox One or PS4 controller. But this Pro controller is a very nice addition to your Nintendo Switch! This Pro controller is much like the Xbox One's (and 360) controller. Cause this time they switched where the right analog and buttons are, like it is on Xbox. The analogs are good, the buttons and triggers/L&R are good. The buttons and D pad are good also. It isn't too heavy nor too light. Plus it has a built in battery that can last around 40hrs per charge. Grip is awesome on it! I highly recommend getting at least one Pro Controller. Personally I plan on getting another 1-2 of them!

The Switch Pro Controller has horrible lag, in my opinion it is unusable for any games where speed it important to the game play.  So for example, it's fine for most RPG's, but useless for arcade games and shooters.  I do not experience the same problems with the out of the box controller setup, so this is specific tot he pro controller.  Do not buy this expecting to use it when low latency is important!

My 4 month old controller is suffering from drift, making it unusable. The drift is do bad that I can not even calibrate the controller in the system settings. If others are suffering from this issue, speak up! Nintendo is selling faulty controllers!

Package was packed really well and received package quickly.  Controller feels great.  I recommend this product if you plan to buy a lot of adventure games with the Switch.  I know the joy cons may have a stylish and sleek feel to it.  The pro controller is still a must have for games like Mario Odyseey, Zelda and FPS games.

It is definitely worth it if you're tired of joy cons. This controller feels like ps4 and xbox had a baby. It's smooth to the touch like the ps4 and grippy like the xbox. Only con is no headphone jack which is why i took off a star.

I was impressed.  This is probably Nintendo's best controller ever.  The placement of the four "secondary" (-,+,screencap,home)  buttons takes some getting used to - especially screencap.  But they are placed probably the best way because you never press them by accident.  This would be a great replacement for XBOX ONE controllers if it's supported on PC.

I've started playing for longer sessions and the standard Joy Con controllers started to cause wrist pain / need frequent recharging. I read reviews and found Nintendo's own pro controller is the best, and indeed it is! I love the long lasting battery life and my hands are comfortable after hours of play. Love that they charge via USB-C!

Si quieres disfrutar de tu switch al 100% en modo tv, es el primer accesorio que recomendaría comprar a cualquier dueño de esta consola. No solo la autonomía es brutal, es completamente ergonómico, peso ideal, joysticks con un recorrido amplio y preciso y el giroscopio se siente perfectamente calibrado. Es muy fácil de instalar y de usar, uno de los mejores mandos que he tenido la oportunidad de probar, me ha brindado una muy satisfactoria experiencia, vale 100% la pena comprarlo.
It works but it's obviously a fake because it's missing nintendo logos! Buyer beware, especially if it's coming from SINGAPORE
I bought this controller for my 12 year old grandson. He loved it! He had another controller but apparently it didn't compare to ease and set up this controller had.

This controller has single-handedly made Animal Crossing a chore.  Moving in the up direction stutters.  Always.  I can’t believe this is an actual Nintendo product.  Wait, I take that back.  Their stuff has always been subpar.

This is a great investment. I do not understand the bickering people are having about the price. All controllers cost $60-70 controllers regardless of system.  The battery life is great, it blows out the other two systems. I charged my controller once, used it for 2 weeks. Ridiculous. Lasts around 40-50 hours. I used it for 10 hrs straight and it didn't even lose one bar yet. Comes with a cable to charge it, which is good. The buttons on the face of the controller are soft. The shoulder buttons are like a PS2 so it's good. Old school/Solid feel, not the soft squeeze triggers are to the new generation or GameCube. Analog has a good range and thumb feels free in motion, clicking it in is the same as other companies. D-PAD is good, used it for Zelda, would use it more for Street fighter. Regardless, it's a good for gaming, if your hardcore it's a definite. If your casual, you would love it. Get one and try it, you can always return it.

It’s incredibly comfortable and seems to offer better response than the joy cons on the switch. However, it isn’t as convenient as the joycons which are nearly always attached to it. It makes it only a good use for games like Doom, Skyrim and a few indies (so far) and then just as good as the joycons for Zelda or Mario. It can also connect to a pc as a bluetooth controller. It’ll get incredible battery life and will be a must when/if Nintendo puts GameCube games on the Switch.

Had this since May, 2017. About 2 months into using it, it just died - would NOT charge and lights would not come on. Was very surprised that it gave out so fast. Luckily, it was still under Nintendo warranty. They sent me a prepaid label and I shipped it out to get fixed. About a week later a new controller showed up. Been using the new controller for few months with no issues so far.

This controller is amazing.  It feels nice and comfortable in my hands.  The price is a little steep, but you are getting a quality product from Nintendo for sure.  The most impressive feature to me is the battery life.  Seldom do I charge this thing.  It lasts MUCH longer than the PS4 controller, or even the Joy-Cons, in my opnion.Highly recommended for Switch owners!

If you have a Switch, you pretty much need this. The JoyCons work fine when you're playing in portable mode, but transform into an uncomfortable angular monstrosity when clipped into the grip for TV play. The Pro Controller is undeniably superior.It's a shame this thing is so expensive, however. And it's likewise a shame that Nintendo have once again decided not to include analog triggers. Those issues keep it short of perfection.
Shoulder buttons no longer register as button presses with light use. Feels food in the hands but it’s otherwise garbage. Get something cheaper so you don’t feel ripped off when it breaks on you.

The main complaints I see about this controller are the Dpad, the lack of headphone jack, and the price.I think the Dpad is great. The lack of headphone jack is definitely a problem, but can be fixed. The xbox one controller used to not have a headphone jack either.

I went through two of these from a local Mart store. They feel fantastic, and when they work they are amazing. The d-pad, the sticks, everything feels wonderful. HOWEVER, joystick drift is an issue. One controller drifted after a few days of use, the second controller drifted right out of the box. So far the drift is only an issue in Super Mario Maker 2, and causes making levels to be practically impossible while fighting the drifting cursor the entire time, forcing me to resort to using joycons. It's possible this caused by a slack in quality control due to Nintendo rushing to get more product out during the pandemic, but maybe not. I've ordered a (hopefully) high quality third party controller to replace the Pro as my primary controller. Your mileage may vary.

Well when I 1st heard the nintendo switch came out it had all the oppertunities and benifits that you can use from the smallest to the biggiest little left side controller to a pro controller so i love this controller then the regular black one is because this one adds more style then just a regular black one and i think its pretty cool :) so this controller earned my 5 stars!

The Pro Controller is subpar in design, its functionality, and it is not suitable for competitive smash ultimate, fighting games, or any Nintendo games, for that matter.  After a couple months of moderate use, the C-Stick broke completely, rendering the entire controller useless and worthless.  Nintendo does not provide warranties on all controllers, so for this expensive piece of hardware, find an alternative.

FAKE PRODUCT. There may be genuine ones in the listing but I received a fake. There's no Nintendo Switch logo anywhere on my controller or the charger that came with it, the NFC functionality doesn't read AT ALL, and it does not turn on the Switch from the Home button like a genuine model. It works perfectly but I am quite disappointed to find out I can't use any amiibos.

A must have accessory for adults! Bought the switch and found out soon after that I needed a controller to play comfortably. This one works great and allows me to enjoy Nintendo’s fun exclusives. It is similar in size and feel to an Xbox controller. Wish I could use this with my PS4, but oh well...
This remote is way better than the JoyCons for any games that don't require the alternative control styles offered by the JoyCons.
The grip is much comfortable than the regular controller comes with the Switch. Buttons are bigger and much lighter.
Out of warranty period left joycon started drifting like many other one star reviews.

Let me start off by saying I never write reviews on here. I just never had a reason to take the time to do so, but I'd write a novel for this controller. It's beyond comfortable to hold, and I know I will have many long hours ahead with it. The buttons all have a good feel, the analog sticks have no deadzone play to them and are super responsive, the D-Pad, while slightly stiff feeling, responds well, and the natural resistance of the triggers feels amazing as they spring back into place.For a die hard gamer and Nintendo fan I highly recommend this controller, even at the steep $70 price tag.

Love the controller, works exactly as you would expect, except for the DPad, which is very hit or miss. Pushing left or right on it can often times cause it to push up or down at the same time, which can become a huge nuisance in Nintendo games, as they often times have very DPad centric games, especially with Cadence of Hyrule that released a bit ago. If anything do your research and find a controller with a much more responsive and consistence DPad.
Bought this for my husband! He love it uses it to ignore me. And now I regret getting it for him. But j guess that make it. Great product for man

Seriously, this is one of the best controllers I've used. This rivals the likes of even the 360 pad and GC pad. The only thing that keeps it from #1 is the fact that the triggers aren't analog. But overall, it's super comfy, the buttons feel awesome, and it's just really, really well made. Highly recommended for all Switch users!

Well as with all officially licensed Nintendo products, this pro controller has been my primary way of playing all of my Nintendo Switch games. Just broke 100 hours inLegend of Zelda Breath of the wild, and we'll over 20 hours in Mario Kart 8 Deluxe. I have charged the controller maybe 3-4 times since purchase. I honestly am curious as to how long this controller will last before I start to see the "problems" that the lower reviewers have encountered. Thank you Nintendo for quality as usual.
The controler stoped working how do you trouble shoot a controller.

Seriously all it takes is your fingernail at the front and you can scratch it, even by the USB-C charging port it can scratch the glossy surface there. Other then that their great controllers haven't had any disconnectivity issues and it feels very nice in the hands, the only reason I'm holding back from giving it 5-stars is that of how easy this thing is to scratch, so watch out if you buy one make sure not to scratch it.
Our son asked for this controller for Christmas. We've been playing quite a bit of Mario Kart and he lets me use his controller. It really works great.

The Nintendo Switch Pro Controller is a solid controller for a solid system. The dimpled grips are very nice, and the buttons feel good to the touch. Although my hands are a bit small, everything feels perfectly spaced. The shoulder buttons are wonderfully large, and the HD Rumble isn't as intrusive as it is for the tiny Joy-Cons. As a controller, I rate it a perfect 10/10.
I wish I got one sooner. The price sucks but it’s worth it. Battery lasts a long time and controllers connects effortlessly. The triggers are light years better than the corded version. Overall 10/10
Best controller I've ever used. The price seems steep at first but once you have this thing in your hands you will understand the price and it will be all worth it.
I like this controller. It’s  easy to set up and use. I also found that I can use it as a gaming controller for the amazon fire stick saved me tons of money in having to buy an amazon controller!

I already have one of these, so this will be my 2nd one. I have rather large hands and this is my preferred method for using the Switch. The JoyCon controllers are just too small and feel too flimsy, so this is great.

This controller looks and feels great! If you're holding off on buying it cause of the "pink" stock photo then don't worry, it's not anywhere near that bright, it's really a deep pink/ deep amaranth color.

I’ve been playing Nintendo since 1986 and am really disappointed in the Pro controller.  I come to expect high quality from Nintendo but the action on the d-pad is terrible, the input lag is unacceptable, and at this price it is an insult. Wonderful addition to the console mode. It feels like an xbox controller. The buttons are not difficult to press however they may need to be broken in somewhat. It can be completely wireless which is great for gyroscope games. It was worth the price for me.

Good controller, but the price is a little steep. Waited and waited for Cyber Monday deals, but am not a fan of the whole "Week" thing. Waiting for a deal to pop up through-out the day. Target got my sale with 3 of these when their sale went online as scheduled. $55 a piece, and happy.

This controller is insanely overpriced and isn't even very comfotable. The fact nintendo peddles low quality products that break very frequently is appalling. I hope nintendo can clean up their act and go back to making good quality products.

I don’t want to shell out $40 or $70 for a new one, but what’s the alternative?
Great controller for a great price.

Simply put, this is one the best controllers on the market, both in comfort and quality.The hardest pill to swallow is the price point. At $70 this is the most expensive, primary, controller on the market. (Except for the Xbox One controller, if you factor in Microsoft's own Play and Charge kit that makes the total $85 MSRP) However once you look past that, this controller offers (almost) everything you could want from a modern console controller.

It's okay. I feel like Nintendo made this different from the Wii U Pro Controller just to say they made it differently. Battery life is incredible on these.  Very comfortable in hand for extended play sessions. My only complaint is lack of a headphone jack

This controller is an absolute must depending on how you primarily use your switch. My only complaint is that the $70 price tag is pretty steep.
